sp.p: Agreed, any thing that breeds mirth is welcome.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Not a word at the Widows, let them go on quietly, and steal their Wedding too.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I heard a Bird sing, as if it were concluded amongst the Couples.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: They have been long about it; my Couze is a girle deserves more haste to her Bed, he has arriv'd there by Carriers Journeys.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p:
But that I hate wooing, by this good day, I like your
Aunt so well and her humour she should scarce be thrown away upon Pale-face, that has sigh'd her into a Wedding Ring, and will but double her Joynture.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why I, thus it should be, pray let us make them the Seat of the war all Dinner, and continue united and true among our selves, then we may defie all forreign danger.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: And with full Bowles let us crown this peace, and sing, Wit, without war, no Mirth doth bring.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: WAs she deaf to your report?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Yes, yes. The Parson walks troubled up and down.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: And ugly, her Abigail, she had her say too?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: And do you walk here biting your Nayls: do you think I'le be satisfy'd with such a way of righting me?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: What would'st have me do?

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Have you no Gall? be abus'd and laugh'd at by a dull Captain, that a strict Muster would turn Fool? you had Wit, and could rail, when I offended you, and none so suddain, none so terrible, none so sure in his Revenge, when I displease you.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Something I'le do.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Do it then, or I shall curse that e're I saw you Death, let the sign of my Lady, an out of fashion whore, that has pay'd for sin, ever since yellow starch and wheel Fardingales were cry'd down, let her Abuse me, and say nothing? if this passes.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: As Christ bless me, but I did (sweet heart:) and if it were not Church livings are mortal, and they are always hitting me in the teeth with a man of your Coat, she should find I am no Church man within, nor Mr. Parson but in my Coat; Come to Dinner, and after Dinner I'le do something.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: I shall do something will vex some body.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Will you please to come to Dinner? the Company stays.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Come, let's go in.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: No, I must walk a little to disgest this breakfast, the guests else will wonder to see I am troubled.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Come, let this day pass in Mirth, spight of mischief, for lucks sake.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: I'le follow you, and do what I can to be merry.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Why, he stands already.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Peace, let me alone, I'le make him Jostle, like the Millers Mare, and stand like the Dun Cow, till thou may'st milk him.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p:
Pray break him of his miserableness, it is one of the chief Exceptions I have against him; he reared a puppy once, till it was ten days old, with three hap 'worth of milk, and then with his own Dagger slew it, and made me dress it: blest my self to see him eat
it, and he bid me beg the Litter, and swore it was sweeter and wholsomer then sucking Rabbets, or London Pigs, which he call'd Belmens issue.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Heark, he calls me, we must humour him a little, he'll Parson calls within. Why sweet heart. rebell else.

div.head: ACT. II. SCEN. VII.
div.stage: Enter (at the windowes) the Widow and Master Careless, Mistress Pleasant and Master Wild, Captain, Master Sad, Constant, Jolly, Secret, a Table and Knives ready for Oysters.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: YOu re welcome all, but especially Master Jolly; no reply, with I thank your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: I beseech you, Sir, let us never be better acquainted.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: I shall endeavour, Lady, and fail in nothing that is in my She speaks to Master Jolly power to dis-oblige you; for there is none more ambitious of your ill Opinion then I.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: I rejoyce at it, for the less Love, the better welcome still.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And as ever you had an ounce of Love for the Widow, be not Friends among your selves.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Aunt, though we were at strife when we were alone, yet now we unite like a Politick State against the common Enemy.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: The common Enemy, what is that?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Women, and Lovers in general.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay, then we have a party Niece, claim; quickly, now is the time, according to the Proverb; Keep a thing seven years, and then if thou hast no use on't throw't away.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Agreed, let's challenge our Servants; by the Love they have profes'd, they cannot in honour refuse to joyn with us; and see where they come.—

div.stage: Enter Sadd and Constant, and meet Secret, she whispers this to Sadd.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.p: Sir, tis done.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Be secret and grave, I'll warrant our design will take as we can wish.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Sweet Mistress Pleasant.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Servant Sadd.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: We are threatened to have a War wag'd against us, will you not second us?

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: With these youths we'll do enough, Madam.

sp.speaker: Widd.
sp.p: I'll swear my Servant gave hit for hit this morning, as if he had been a Master in the Noble Science of Wit.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Mine laid about him with spik and span new Arguments, not like the same Man, his old sayings and Presidents laid by.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Thus arm'd, then, we'll stand and defie them.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p:
Where's your Points, sure Aunt, this should be your
Wedding day, for you have taken the Man for better for worse.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No, Nephew, this will not prove the day that we shall either give or take a Ring.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Hang me, if I know you can go back again with your Honour.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Or in Justice refuse him Liberty, that has serv'd out his time; either marry him or provide for him, for he is maim'd in your service.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why Servant Sadd? you'll arm; my Nephew has thrown the first dart at you.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Hast hit, hast hit?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No, Captain, 'twas too wide.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Too wide? Marry he's an ill Marks-man that shoots wider then a Widow.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: We are both in one hole, Captain; but I was loath to venture my Opinion, lest her Ladyship should think I was angry; for I have a good mind to fall upon the Widow.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: You're a constant Man, Master Jolly; you have been in that mind this twelve-months day.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: You are in the right, Madam; she has it to shew under his hand, but she will not come in the List with him again; she threw him the last year.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Come, shall we eat Oysters? Who's there? call for some Wine, Master Jolly; you are not warm yet, pray be free, you are at home.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Your Ladyship is merry.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You do not take it ill, to have me assure you you are at home here?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Such another invitation (though in jest) will take away Master Sadds stomack. Oysters net brought in yet.

sp.speaker: Sad.
sp.p: No, faith, Ned, though she should take him, it will not take away my stomack; my Love is so fix'd I may wish my wishes, but she shall never want them to wait upon hers.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: A Traytor, bind him, has pull'd down a side; profess your Love thus publick?

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: I by my faith, continue Master Sadd, give it out you Love, and call it a new Love, a Love never seen before, we'll all come to it as your Friends.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Gentlemen, still I Love; and if she to whom I thus sacrifice will not reward it, yet the worst Malice can say, is, I was unfortunate and misfortunate; not false made me so.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: In what Chapter shall we find this written, and what verse? you should preach with a Method, Master Sadd.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Gentlemen, if ever he spoke so much dangerous sence before (either of Love or Reason) hang me.

sp.speaker: Sad.
sp.p: Madam, my Love is no news where you are; Know, your scorn has made it publick; and though it could gain no return from you; yet others have esteemed me for the Faith and Constancy I have pay'd here.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p:
Did not I foretell you of his Love? I foresaw this danger,
shall I never live to see Wit and Love dwell together?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I am but a poor Souldier, and yet never reach'd to the Honour of being a Lover; yet from my own observations, Master Sadd, take a Truth; 'tis a folly to believe any Woman loves a Man for being constant to another, they dissemble their hearts onely; and hate a Man in Love worse then a Wencher.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: And they have Reason; for if they have the grace to be kind, he that loves the Sex may be theirs.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: When your constant Lover, if a Woman have a mind to him, and be blest with so much grace to discover it; He, out of the noble mistake of Honour hates her for it, and tells it perchance, and preaches Reason to her Passion, and cryes, miserable Beauty, to be so unfortunate as to inhabit in so much frailty.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: This counsel makes her hate him more then she lov'd before; These are troubles, those that love are subject to, while we look on and laugh, to see both thus slav'd while we are free.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: My prayers still shall be, Lord deliver me from Love.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: 'Tis Plague, Pestilence, Famine, Sword, and sometimes sudden death.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Yet I love, I must love, I will love, and I do love.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: In the present tense.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No more of this Argument, for Loves sake.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: By any means, Madam, give him leave to love, and you are resolv'd to walk tied up in your own Armes, with your Love as visible in your Face, as your Mistresses colours in your Hat; that any Porter at Charing-Cross may take you like a Letter at the Carriers, and having read the superscription, deliver Master Sadd to the fair hands of Mistress or my Lady such a one, lying at the sign of the hard heart.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: And she, if she has wit (as I believe she hath) will scarce pay the Post for the Pacquet.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Treason, how now Niece, joyn with the Enemy?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: A health, Ned, what shall I call it? They give the Captain Wine.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: To Master Sadd, he needs it that avowes himself a Lover.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you have the Advantage, the Time, the Place, the Company; But we may meet when your wits shall not have such advantage as my Love.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: No more of Love, I am so sick on't.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: By your Pardon, Mistress, I must not leave Love thus unguarded, I vow my self his follower.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Much good may Love do him, give me a Glass of Wine here; Will, let them keep company with the blind Boy, give us his Mother, and let them preach again; hear that will, he has good luck, perswades me 'tis an ugly sin to lie with a handsome Woman.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
A pox upon my Nurse, she frighted me so when I was young with stories of the Devil, I was almost fourteen er'e I could prevail with Reasons to unbind my Reason, it was so slav'd to Faith and Conscience; she made me believe Wine was an evil spirit,
and Fornication was like the Whore of Babylon, a fine face, but a Dragon under her Pety-coats; and that made me have a mind to peep under all I met since.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Fie, fie, for shame, do not talk so; are you not asham'd to glory in sin, as if variety of women were none.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Madam, we do not glory in Fornication; and yet I thank God, I cannot live without a woman.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why, do's your Ladiship think it a sin to lye with variety of handsome women? if it be, would I were the wicked'st man in the company.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: You have been mark'd for an indifferent sinner; that way Captain.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Who I? No faith, I was a fool, but and I were to begin again, I would not do as I have done, I kept one; but if ever I keep another, Hang me; nor would I advise any friend of mine to do it.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Why, I am sure 'tis a provident and safe way; a man may always be provided and sound.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Fie upon this discourse.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Those considerations betrayed me, A pox; it is a dull sin to travel, like a Carriers-horse, always one Road.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Fie, Captain, repent for shame, and Marry.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Your Ladiship would have said, Marry, and repent; No, though it be not the greatest pleasure, yet it is better then marrying; for when I am weary of her, my unconstancy is term'd vertue, and I shall be said to turn to grace. Beware of women, for better for worse; for our wicked nature, when her sport is lawful, cloyes straight; therefore, rather then Marry keep a Wench.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Faith, he is in the right, for 'tis the same thing in number and kind; and then the sport is quickned, and made poynant with sin.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yet 'tis a fault, faith, and I'll perswade all my friends from it; especially here where any innovation is dangerous; 'twas the newness of the sin that made me suffer in the opinion of my friends; and I was condemned by all sorts of people; not that I sinn'd, but that I sinn'd no more.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Why I, hadst thou been wicked in fashion, and privily lain with ev'ry body, their guilt would have made them protect thee; so that to be more wicked is to be innocent at lest safe; A wicked world, Lord help us.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
But being particular to her, and not in love, nor subject to it, taking an Antidote ev'ry morning, before I venture into those infectious places where Love Beauty dwells; this enraged the Maiden, Beauties of the Time, who thought it a prejudice to their Beauties to see me careless, and securely pass by their conquering eyes; my name being found amongst none of those that deckt their Triumphs. But from this 'tis easie to be safe, for their Pride will not let them love, nor my leisure me. Then the old Ladies that pay for their pleasures; they, upon the news, beheld me with their natural frowns, despairing when their money could not prevail;
and hated me when they heard that I for my pleasure would pay as large as they.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Gentlemen, take warning; a Fee from ev'ry man; For by this day, there's strange counsel in this confession.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Captain, you forget to pledge Mr. Careless; here, will you not drink a cup of wine, who's there? Bring the Oysters.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, if you please.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Proceed, Captain.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Fie, Mr. Wild, are you not asham'd to encourage him to this filthy discourse.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: A glass of wine then; and I'll drink to all the new married Wives that grieve to think, at what rate their Fathers purchase a little husband. These when they lie thirsting for the thing they paid so dear for.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: These, methinks, should be thy friends, and point thee out as a man for them.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes, till the faithful Nurse cries; Alas, Madam, he keeps such a one, he has enough at home; then she swells with envy and rage against us both, calls my Mistress ugly, common, unsafe; and me, a weak secure fool.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: These are strange truths, Madam.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I, I, but these Oysters are a better jest.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: But she's abus'd that will let such reason tame her desire, and a fool in Loves School; else she would not be ignorant that variety is such a friend to love, that he which rises a sunk coward from the Ladies bed would find new fires at her Maids; nor ever yet did the man want fire, if the woman would bring the fuel.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: For Gods sake, leave this discourse.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: The Captain has a mind we should eat no Oysters.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Aunt, we came to be merry, and we will be merry, and you shall stay it out; Proceed Captain.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Fie Captain, I'me asham'd to hear you talk thus: Marry, then you will have a better opinion of women.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Marry! yes, this knowledge will invite me, it is a good encouragement, is it not think you? What is your opinion? were not these Marriages made in Heaven? By this good day, all the world is mad, and makes haste to be fool'd, but we four: And I hope there's none of us believes there has any Marriages been made in Heaven, since Adam.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: By my faith, 'tis thought the Devil gave the Ring there to.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nephew, I'll swear I'll be gone.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
Hold her, Ned, she goes not yet; there's a fourth kind of women that concerns her more then all the rest, Ecce signum— She is He points to Sadd. one of those who, cloathed in Purple, triumph over their dead husbands; these will be caught at first sight, and at first sight must be catcht; 'tis a Bird that must be shot flying, for they never sit; if a man delay they cool, and fall into considerations of Joynture, and friends opinion; in which time, if she hears thou keep'st a Wench, thou had'st better be a Beggar in her opinion; for then her Pride, it may be, would betray her to the vanity of setting up a proper
man; (as they call it) but for a Wencher no Argument prevails with your Widow; for she believes they have spent too much that way, to be able to pay her due benevolence.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: As I live, I'll be gone if you speak one word more of this uncivil subject.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Captain, let me kiss thy cheek, for that Widow; you understand this, Widow? I say no more; Here Captain, here's to thee; as it goes down, A pox of care.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Jesus! Mr. Jolly, have you no observations of the Court, that are so affected with this of the Town?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Faith, they say, there's good sport there, sometimes.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Mr. Jolly is afraid to let us partake of his knowledge.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: No faith, Madam.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: By this drink, if he stay till I have eaten a few more, I'll describe it.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: What should I say, 'tis certain the Court is the bravest place in the Kingdom, for sport, if it were well lookt to, and the Game preserved fair; But as 'tis, a man may sooner make a set in the Strand. And it will never be better, whil'st your divine Lovers inhabit there.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Let the King make me Master of the Game.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: And admit us Laiety-lovers.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: I would he would; for as 'tis, there's no hopes amongst the Ladies; besides, 'tis such an example to see a King and Queen good, Husband and Wife, that to be kind will grow out of fashion.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Nay, that's not all, for the women grow malicious, because they are not courted; nay, they bred all the last mischiefs, and call'd the Kings chastity a neglect of them.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Thou art in the right; An Edward, or a Harry, with seven Queens in Buckram, that Haught among the men, and Stroakt the women, are the Monarchs they wish to bow to; they love no tame Princes, but Lyons in the Forest.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why, and those were properly call'd the Fathers of their People, that were indeed akine to their Nobility; now they wear out their youth and beauty, without hope of a monumental Ballad, or Trophee of a Lie-bell that shall hereafter point at such a Lord, and cry that is the royal Son of such a one.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: And these were the ways that made them powerful at home; for the City is a kind of tame Beast; you may lead her by the horns any whither, if you but tickle them in the ear sometimes. Queen Bess, of famous memory, had the trick on't; and I have heard them say, In Eighty eighty, er'e I was born, as well I can remember, she rode to Tilbury on that bonny Beast, the Mayor.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I would I might counsel him; I'de so reform the Court.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Never too soon; for now, when a stranger comes in, and spies a Covey of a Beauties, would make a Faulconer unhood, before he can draw his Leash he is warn'd that's a markt Partridge; and that, and ev'ry he, has by their example a particular she.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p:
By this light, the six fair Maids stand like the Working-days in the Almanack; one with A scored upon her breast, that is
as much to say, I belong to such a Lord; the next with B for an elder Brother; C for such a Knight; D possest with melancholy, and at her breast you may knock an hour er'e you get an answer, and then she'l tell you there's no lodging there; she has a constant fellow Courtier that has taken up all her heart to his own use: in short, All are dispos'd of, but the good Mother; and she comes in like the Sabbath, at the weeks end; and I warrant her make any one rest that comes at her.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I marry; but if she were like the Jews Sabbath, it were somewhat; but this looks like a Broken Commandment, that has had more work done upon her, then all the week besides.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: And what think you, is not this finely carryed? you that are about the King, counsel him, if he will have his sport fair, he must let the Game be free, as it has been in former Ages; then a stranger that has wit, good means, and handsome cloaths, no sooner enters the privy Chamber, and beat about with three graceful legs, but he spring a Mistress that danc'd as well as he, Sung better, as free as fair; those at first sight could speak, for wit is always acquainted: These fools must be akin er'e they can speak; and now the friends make the bargain, and they go to Bed er'e they know why.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Faith, he's in the right, you shall have a Buzzard now hover and beat after a pretty Wench, till she is so weary of him she's forc'd to take her Bed for covert, and find less danger in being truss'd then in flying.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: And what becomes of all this pudder, after he has made them sport for one night, to see him towse the Quarry, he carries her into the Country, and there they two fly at one another till they are weary.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: And all this mischief comes of Love and Constancy; we shall never see better days till there be an Act of Parliament against it; Enjoyning Husband not to Till their Wives, but change and lay them fallow.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: A pox, the women will never consent to it; they'l be till'd to death first.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you are very bold with the sex.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, it is our care of them; why you see they are married at fourteen, yield a Crop and a half, and then dye, 'tis meerly their love that destroys'em; for if they get a good husbandman, the poor things yield their very hearts.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: And do you blame their loves, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: No, not their love, but their discretion; let them love, and do, a Gods name; but let them do with discretion.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: But how will you amend this?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Instead of two Beds and a Physitian; I'de have the State prescribe two Wives and a Mistress.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Ho! it will never be granted; the State is made up of old men, and they find work enough with one.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p:
We will petition the lower House, there are young men, and (if it were but to be factious) would pass it, if they thought
the upper house would Cross it; Besides, they ought to do it, Death! they provide against cutting down old Trees, and preserving high-ways and Post-horses, and let pretty Wenches run to decay?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Why may it not come within the Statute of Depopulation? As I live, the State ought to take care of those Pretty creatures; Be you Judge, Madam; Is't not a sad sight to see a rich young Beauty, with all her Innocence and Blossoms on, subject to some rough rude Fellow, that ploughs her; and esteems and uses her as a chattel, till she is so lean, a man may finde as good Grass upon the Common, where it may be shee'le sit coughing with sunk Eyes, so weak that a Boy (with a Dog) that can but whistle, may keep a score of them?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You are strangely charitable to Our Sex, on a sudden.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I know not what they are; but for my part, I'le be a Traytor ere I'le look on, and see Beauty go thus to wrack; it is enough, custom has made us suffer them to be enclos'd; I am sure, they were created common, and for the use of Man, and not intended to be subject to jealousie and choler, or to be bought or sold, or let for term of lives or years, as they are now, or else sold at Out-crys; Oh! Yes; who'le give most take her.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why do not some of you, Excellent men, Marry, and mend all these Errours, by your good Example?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Because we want Fortunes, to buy rich wives, or keep poor ones, and be loath to get Beggars, or whores, as well as I love 'em.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Why, are all their Children so that have no fortune think you?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: No, not all; I have heard of Whittington and his Cat, and others, that have made Fortunes by strange means; But I scarce believe my Son would rise from Hope, a half peny, and a Lambs-skin; And the Wenches commonly having more Wit & Beauty then Money, foreseeing small Portions, grow sad, and read Romances, till their Wit spie some unfortunate merit like their own, without money too, and they two sigh after one another, till they grow mysterious in Colours, and become a Proverb for their constancy; and when their Love has worn out the cause, marry in the end a new Couple, then grown asham'd of the knowledge they so long hunted, at length part, by consent, and vanish into Abigail and Governour.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Well Gentlemen, Excuse me for this One time; and if ever I invite you to Dinner again, punish me with such another discourse, in the mean time let's go in and dine, meat stays for us.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Faith Madam, we were resolved to be merry; We have not met these three years till to day, and at the Bear we meant to have din'd; and since your Ladyship would have Our Company, you must pardon Our humour; here Mistriss Sadd, here's the Widows health to you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: NEphew, how do you dispose of your self this afternoon?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: We have a design we must pursue, which will rid you of all this troublesome Company; and wee'l make no Excuse, because you peeped into our privacies to day.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Your humble servant, Ladies; Gentlemen, wee'l leave you to pursue your fortunes.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Farewel Widow, may'st thou live unmarryed till thou run'st away with thy self.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No, no, When that day comes, Command the humblest of your Servants.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Farewel Aunt; sweet Mistris Pleasant, I wish you good fortune.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Farewel, farewel Gentlemen; Niece, now if we could be rid of these troublesome Lovers too, we would go see a Play.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Rid of them? Why, they are but now in season; as I live, She speaks aside .I would do as little to give mine content as any she in Town, and yet I do not grudge him the happiness of carrying me to a Play.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I, but the world will talk, because they pretend; and then we shall be sure to meet my Nephew there, and his wil'd Company, and they will laugh to see us together.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Who will you have? Tym the Butler, or Formal your Gentleman Usher? I would take Philip the foreman of the shop assoon.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Let's mask our selves, and take Secret, and go alone by water.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Yes, and follow her like one of my Aunts of the Suburbs; it is a good way to know what you may yield in a Market; for I'le undertake, there are those shall bid for you before the play will be done.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.p: As I live, Madam, Mistriss Pleasant is in the right; I had such a kindness offer'd me once, and I came to a price with him in knavery; and hang me, if the Rogue was not putting the earnest of his affection into my hand.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Let's go to the Glass-house then.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: I'le go to a Play with my Servant, and so shall you; hang Opinion, and wee'le go to the Glass-house afterwards; it is too hot to Sup early.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.p: Pray Madam go, they say 'tis a fine Play, and a Knight writ it.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Pray let Secret prevail, I'le propose it to the Lovers; in the mean time go you, and bid the Coachman make ready the Coach.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.p: Alas, Madam, hee's sick, poor fellow, and gone to bed, he could not wait at Dinner.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sick?

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Why, see how all things work for the young men, either their Coach, or a Foot; Mr. Constant, what think you of seeing a Play this afternoon? is it not too hot to venture, this Infectious time?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Fie, Madam, there's no danger, the Bill decreas'd Twenty last week.

sp.speaker: Sad.
sp.p: I swear, they say, 'tis a very good Play to day.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Shall we go, Niece?

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Faith 'tis hot, and there's no body but we.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Do's that hinder? pray Madam, grudge us not the favour of venturing your self in Our company.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Come, leave this Ceremony, I'le go in, and put on my Mask; Secret shall bring you yours;

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: No, I'le go, and put it on within.

div.head: ACT. III. SCEN. II.
div.stage: Enter Wild, Careless, Captain and Jolly.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: BY this day, you have netled the Widow.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: The Captain neglected his dinner for his mirth, as if he had forgot to eat.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: When did he oversee his drinking so?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Gentlemen, still it is my fortune to make your worships Merry.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: As I live, Captain, I subscribe, and am content to hold my wit as Tenant to thee; and to night I'le invite you to Supper, where it shall not be lawful to speak till thou has victual'd thy Man of War.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Shall's be merry? what shall we have?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Half a score dishes of meat, choose them your self.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Provide me then the Chines fry'd, and the Salmon Calver'd, a Carp, and black sawce, Red-Dear in the blood, and an Assembly of Woodcocks, and Jack-snipes, so fat you would think they had their winding Sheets on; And upon these, as their Pages, let me have wait your Sussex Wheat-Ear, with a Feather in his Cap; Over all which let our Countrey-man, General Chyne of Beef, Command: I hate your French pottage, that looks as the Cook maid had more hand in it then the Cook.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I'le promise you all this.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: And let me alone to Cook the Fish.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You Cook it? No, no, I left an honest fellow in Town, when I went into Italy, Signiour Ricardo Ligones, one of the ancient house of the Armenian Ambassadours; if he be alive he shall be our Cook.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Is he so Excellent at it?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Excellent? You shall try, you shall try; Why, I tell you, I saw him once dress a shooing-horn, and a Joyners apron, that the Company left Pheasant for it.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: A Shooing-horn?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes, a shooing-horn; marry, there was Garlick in the Sawce.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Is this all you would have?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: This, and a Bird of Paradise, to entertain the rest of the night, and let me alone to Cook her.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: A Bird of Paradise, what's that?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: A Girl of Fifteen, smooth as Satten, White as her Sunday Apron, Plump, and of the first down: I'le take her with her guts in her Belly, and warm her with a Countrey dance or two, then pluck her, and lay her dry betwixt a couple of sheets; There pour into her so much oyl of Wit as will make her turn to a man, & stick into her heart three corns of whole love, to make her taste of what she is doing, then having strewed a man all over her, shut the door, and leave us, wee'le work our selves into such a Sauce as you can never surfeit on, so Poynant and yet no Hogough; Take heed of a hogough, your Onion and woman make the worst sawce; This shook together by an English Cook (for your French seasoning spoils many a woman) and there's a Dish for a King.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: For the first Part, I'le undertake.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: But this for Supper; Capt. No more of this now; This afternoon, as you are true to the Pettycoat, observe your Instructions, and meet at Neds house in the Evening.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: We will not fail.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I must write to Wanton, to know how things stand at home, and to acquaint her how we have thrived with the Old Lady to day.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Whither will you go to write?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: To thy house, 'tis hard by, there's the Fleece.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Do, and in the mean time I'le go home and dispatch a little business, and meet you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Make haste then.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Where shall I meet you?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Whither shall we go till it be time to attend the design.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Let's go to Court for an hour.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Do, I'le meet you at the Queens side.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No, prithee, we are the Mounsieurs new come Over; and if we go fine they will laugh at Us, and think we believe Our selves so; if not, then they will abuse our cloaths, and swear we went into France onely to have our cloaks cut shorter.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Will you go see a Play?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Do, and thither I'le come to you, if it be none of our Gentlemen Poets, that excuse their writings with a Prologue that professes they are no Scholars.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: On my word this is held the best penn'd of the time, and he has writ a very good Play; By this Day, it was extreamly applauded.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Do's he write Plays by the day; Indeed a man would ha judged him a labouring Poet.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: A Labouring Poet? by this hand hee's a Knight; upon my recommendation venture to see it; hang me if you be not extreamly well satisfied.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: A Knight and write Playes? it may be, but 'tis strange to us; so they say there are other Gentlemen Poets without Land or Latine; this was not ordinary; prithee when was he knighted?

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: In the North; the last great knighting, when 'twas Gods great Mercy we were not all Knights.

sp.speaker: VVild.
sp.p: I'll swear, they say, there are Poets that have more Men in Liveries, then Books in their studies.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: And what think you, Gentlemen, are not these things to start a Man? I believe 'tis the first time you have found them lie at the sign of the Page, Foot-men and gilded Coaches; They were wont to lodge at the thin Cloak, they and their Muses made up the Family; And thence sent Scenes to their Patrons, like Boyes in at windowes, and one would return with a Dublett, another with a pair of Breeches, a third with a little ready Money; which, together with their credit with a company, in three Tearms you rarely saw a Poet repaired.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: This truth no body denies.

sp.speaker: VVild.
sp.p: Prithee let us resolve what we shall do, lest we meet with some of them: for it seemes they swarm, and I fear nothing like a Dedication, though it be but of himself; For I must hear him say more then either I deserve or he believes; I hate that in a Poet, they must be dull, or all upon all Subjects; so that they can oblige none but their Muse.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: I perceive by this you will not see the Play; what think you of going to Sims, to Bowles, till I come?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Yes, if you will go to see that Comedy; but there is no reason we should pay for our coming in, and Act too; like some whose interest in the Timber robs them of their Reason, and they run as if they had stolne a Byass.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Resolve what you will do, I am contented.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Let's go walk in the Spring-garden.

sp.speaker: VVild.
sp.p: I'll do it for Company, but I had as live be rid in the Horse-market, as walk in that fools faire; where neither wit nor money is, nor sure to take up a Wench; there's none but honest Women.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: A pox on't, what should we do there? let's go and cross the Field to Pikes, her kitching is cool Winter and Summer.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I like that motion well, but we have no time, and I hate to do that business by halfe; after Supper, if you will, we'll go and make a night on't.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well, I must go write, therefore resolve of somewhat; shall I propose an indifferent place where 'tis probable we shall all meet.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Go you before to the Devil, and I'll make haste after.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Agreed, we shall be sure of good Wine there and in Fresco, for he is never without Patent snow.

sp.speaker: VVild.
sp.p: Patent snow, what doth that project hold?

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Yes, faith, and now there is a Commission appointed for Toasts against the next Winter.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Marry, they are wise, and fore-saw the Parliament, and were resolv'd their Monopolies should be no grievance to the People.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Farewell, you will be sure to meet.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Yes, yes.

div.head: ACT. III. SCEN. III.
div.stage: Enter Wanton and her Maid, with her lap full of things.

sp.speaker: VVant.
sp.p: BId them ply him close and flatter him, and rail upon the old Lady and the Captain; and, do you hear, give him some hints to begin the story of his life, do it handsomely, and you shall see how the Sack will clip his tongue.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: I warrant you, I'll fit him.

sp.speaker: VVant.
sp.p: When he is in his discourse, leave him and come down into the Parlour, and steal away his box with the false Rings that stands by his bed-side; I have all his little Plate here already.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Make you haste, I'll warrant you I'll dress him.

div.head: ACT. III. SCEN. IV.
div.stage: Enter the Captain with a Letter in his hand, and his Boy to him with a Candle, his going to write the superscription.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: SIR, the Lady Love-all passed by even now.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: The Lady Love-all? which way went she.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: To the rich Lady the Widow, where your Worship dined.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter; here, carry this Letter, and bring an answer to the Devil quickly; and tell her we'll stay there till the time be fit for the design.

div.head: ACT. III. SCEN. V.
div.stage: Enter Careless, Wild, and a Drawer, at the Devil.

sp.speaker: Careless.
sp.p: JAck, How goes the world? Bring us some bottles of the best Wine.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: You shall, Sir; your Worship is welcome into England.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Why look you, who sayes a Drawer can say nothing, but anan, anan, Sir? score a quart of Sack in the half-moon.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Your Worship is merry; but I'll fetch you that, Sir, shal speak Greek, and make your Worship prophecy, you drank none such in your journey.

sp.speaker: VVild.
sp.p: Do it then, and make a hole in this Angell thou maist creep through; who is't that peepes, a Fidler? Bring him by the Gives him an Angel .Ears.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: A Taylor, an't like your Worship.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: A Taylor? hast thou a stout Faith?

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: I have had, an't like your Worship; But now I am in despair.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Why then thou art damn'd; go, go home, and throw thy self into thine own Hell, it is the next way to the other.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: I hope your Worship is not displeas'd.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: What dost do here? a Taylor without faith, dos't come to take measure of ours?

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: No, I come to speak with one Master Jolly, a Courtier, a very fine spoken Gentleman, and a just Compter, but one of the worst pay-masters in the world.

sp.speaker: VVild.
sp.p: As thou lov'st me, let's keep him here till he comes, and make him valiant with Sack that he may urge him till he beates Aside .him; we shall have the sport, and be reveng'd upon the Rogue for dunning a Genleman in a Tavern.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I'll charge him: Here drink, poor fellow, and stay in the next room till he comes.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: I thank your Worship, but I am fasting; and if it please your Worship to call for a dozen of Manchets that I may eat a crust first, then I'll make bold with a glass of your Sack.

sp.speaker: VVild.
sp.p: Here, here, drink in the mean time, fetch him some bread.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: Will your Worship have me drink all this vessel of Sack?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Yes, yes, off with't, 'twill do you no harm. The Taylor drinkes.

sp.speaker: VVild.
sp.p: Why do you not take some Order with that Jolly to make him pay thee?

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: I have petition'd him often, but can do no good.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: A pox upon him, petition him, his heart is hardned to ill, threaten to arrest him; nothing but Serjeant can touch his Conscience.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: Truly, Gentlemen, I have reason to be angry, for he uses me ill, when I ask him for my money. Jolly speakes within.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Where is Master VVild, and Master Careless?

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: I hear his voice.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Let the Coach stay. How now, who would he speak with?

sp.speaker: VVild.
sp.p: Do not you know?

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Yes, and be you Judge if the Rogue does not suffer deservedly; I have bid him any time this twelve moneth but send his wife, and I'll pay her, and the Rogue replyes, no body shall lie with his wife but himself.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Nay, if you be such a one.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: No more they shall not, I am but a poor man.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: By this hand, he's drunk.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: Nay then, I arrest you in mine own Name at his Majesties Suit.

sp.speaker: VVild.
sp.p: As I live, thou shalt not beat him.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Beat him? I'll kiss him, I'll pay him, and carry him about with me, and be at the charge of Sack to keep him in the humour.

sp.speaker: Taylor.
sp.p: Help, rescue, I'll have his body, no Bayle shall serve. He hugs the quart pot.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Sir, yonder is a Gentleman would speak with you; I do not like his followers.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: What are they, Bailiffs?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: Little better.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Send him up alone, and stand you ready at the Stairs feet.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: How can that be?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: It is the Scrivener at the Corner, pick a Quarrel with him for coming into our Company; the Drawers will be armed behind them, and we will so rout the Rascals; take your swords, and let him sleep.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: What Scrivener?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Cropp the Brownist, he that the Ballad was made on.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: What Ballad?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Have not you heard of the Scriveners Wife that brought the Black-moore from the holy Land, and made him a Brownist; and in pure charity lay with him, and was deliver'd of a Mag-Pie; a pied Prophet; which when the elect saw, they prophesi'd, if it liv'd, 'twould prove a great enemy to their Sect; for the Mid-wife cri'd out, 'twas born a Bishop, with Tippet and white-sleeves; at which the zealous Mother cri'd, Down with the Idoll; so the Mid-wife and she in pure devotion kill'd it.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Kill'd it? what became of them?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Why, they were taken and condemn'd, and suffer'd under a Catholick Sheriff, that afflicted them with the Letany all the way from New-gate to the Gallows, which in Rog'ry he made to be set up Altar-wise too, and hang'd them without a Psalm.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: But how took they that breach of Priviledge?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: I know not, Gregory turn'd them off, and so they descended, and became Brown-martyrs.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: And is the husband at door now?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Yes, yes, but he's married again to a rich Widow at Wapping, a Wench of another temper, one that you cannot please better then by abusing him; I always pick quarrels with him, that she may reconcile us, the peace is always worth a dinner, at least. Hark, I hear him.— Save you Mr. Cropp, you are come in the nick to pledge a health.

sp.speaker: Crop.
sp.p: No, Sir, I have other business, shall I be paid my money, or no?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Yes. Jolly drinks.

sp.speaker: Crop.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: You asked whether you should be paid your money, or no, and I said, Yes.

sp.speaker: Crop.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, be plain.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: And be you so, Sir; how durst you come into this Room, and company, without leave?

sp.speaker: Crop.
sp.p: Sir, I have come into good Lords company, er'e now.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p:
It may be so, but you shall either fall upon your knees,
and pledge this health, or you come no more into Lords companies, no, By these hilts.

sp.speaker: Crop.
sp.p: 'Tis Idolatry; Do, martyr me, I will not kneel, nor joyn They tug him and make him kneel .in sin with the wicked.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Either kneel, or I'll tear thy Cloak, which by the age and looks, may be that which was writ for in the time of the Primitive Church.

sp.speaker: Crop.
sp.p: Pay me, and I'll wear a better; it would be honestlier done, then to abuse this, and prophane the Text; a Text that shews your Bishops in those days wore no Lawn-sleeves; and you may be asham'd to protect him that will not pay his debts; The cries of the Widow will come against you for it.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Remember, Sirrah, the dinners and suppers, fat Venison and good words, I was fain to give you, Christning your Children still, by the way of Brokadge; count that charge, and how often I have kept you from fining for Sheriff, and thou art in my debt; then I am damn'd for speaking well of thee so often against my conscience, which you never consider.

sp.speaker: Crop.
sp.p: I am an honest man, Sir.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Then ushering your wife, and Mistress Ugly her daughter, to Plays and Masques at Court; you think these courtesies deserve nothing in the hundred; 'tis true, they made room for themselves with their dagger Elbows; and when Spider your daughter laid about her with her breath, the Devil would not have sat neer her.

sp.speaker: Crop.
sp.p: You did not borrow my money with this language.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: No, Sirrah; then I was fain to flatter you, and endure the familiarity of your family, and hear (nay fain sometimes to joyn in) the lying praises of the holy Sister that expir'd at Tyburn.

sp.speaker: Crop.
sp.p: Do, abuse her, and be curst; 'tis well known she dy'd a He offers to go, and Jolly stays him. martyr; and her blood will be upon some of you, 'tis her Orphans money I require; and this is the last time I'll ask it, I'll find a way to get it.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Ar't serious? By that light, I'll consent, and take it for an infinite Obligation if thou wilt teach the rest of my Creditors that trick; 'twill save me a world of labour; For, hang me if I know how to do't.

sp.speaker: Crop.
sp.p: Well, Sir, since I see your resolution, I shall make it my business.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Prithee, let's be rid of this fool.

sp.speaker: Crop.
sp.p: Fool? let him pay the fool his money, and he'l be gone.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: No, Sir, not a farthing; 'twas my business to borrow it, and it shall be yours to get it in again; nay, By this hand, I'll be feasted too, and have good words; nay, thou shalt lend me more er'e thou get'st this again.

sp.speaker: Crop.
sp.p: I'll lay my Action upon you.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Your Action you Rogue, lay two. They kick him and thrust him out the room.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Lay three for Battery; What have we here? a she Creditor too? who would she speak with?

div.stage: Enter Faithful, Wild and Careless return and meet her.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: She looks as if she had trusted in her time.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Would you speak with any here, old Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: My business is to Mr. Jolly.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: From your self, or are you but a Messenger?

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: My business, Sir, is from a Lady.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: From a Lady? from what Lady, pray? Why so coy?

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: From a Lady in the Town.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Hoh! hoh! from a Lady in the Town; Is it possible I should have guest you came from a Lady in the Suburbs, or some Country-madam, by your riding face?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: I think we have routed the Rascals. Faithful? what makes thy gravity in a Tavern?

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: Sport, it seems, for your saucy companions.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Ho, ho, Mull, ho; No Fury, Faithful.

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: 'Tis well, Sir; my Lady presents her service to you, and hath sent you a Letter, there's my business.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Prithee, who is her Lady?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: The Lady Love-all.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Oh, oh, do's she serve that old Lady? God help her.

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: God help her: Pray for your self, Sir, my Lady scorns your prayers.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Faithful, come hither; Prithee is thy Lady drunk?

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: Drunk, Sir?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: I, drunk, or mad, she'd never writ this else; she requires me, here, to send back by you the Pearl she gave me this morning; which sure she'd never do if she were sober; for you know, I earn'd them hard.

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: I know? What do I know? you will not defame my Lady, will you?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: By no means, this is by way of counsel; fie, give a thing, and take a thing; if he did not perform, he shall come at night, and pay his scores.

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: 'Tis well, Sir; is this your return for my Ladies Favours? shall I have the Pearl, Sir?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: No; and tell her 'tis the opinion of us all, he that opens her stinking Oyster is worthy of the Pearl.

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: You are a foul-mouth'd fellow, Sirrah; and I shall live to see you load a Gallows, when my Lady shall find the way to her own again.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: If she miss, there are divers can direct her, you know; adieu, Faithful, do you hear? steal privately down by the back-door, lest some knavish Boy spie thee, and call thine age, Baud.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Prithee, who is this thing?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p:
'Tis my Ladies Waiting-woman, her Baud, her she Confesor, her self at second hand; her beginning was simple and below stairs, till her Lady finding her to be a likely promising Baud; secret
as the Key at her Girdle, obedient as her thoughts, those vertues rais'd her from the flat Peti-coat, and Kercher, to the Gorget and Bum-roll; and I remember 'twas good; sport at first, to see the Wench perplext with her Metamorphosis; she since has been in love with all the Family, and now sighs after the Levite; and if he forsake her too, I prophesie, a Waiting-womans curse will fall upon her, to dye old, despis'd, poor, and out of fashion.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why do you not hang out a painted cloath? and take two pence a piece, and let in all the tame fools at door, those sons of wonder that now gape, and think you mad.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter what they think, madness is proper here; are not Taverns Bacchus his Temples, the place of madness, Do's not the sign of madness hang out at the door?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: While we within possess our joys and cups, as full of pleasure as weeping Niobe's afflicted eyes were swell'd with grief and tears; Blessing on the cause that made our joys thus compleat; for see Plutus in our Pockets, Mars by our sides, Bacchus in our head, self-love in our hearts, and change of Virgins in our Arms, Beauties whose eyes and hearts speak love and welcome; No rigid thinkers, no niggard beauties that maliciously rake up their fire in green sickness to preserve a spark that shall flame only in some dull day of Marriage; let such swear and forswear, till (of the whole Parish) they love each other least, whil'st we wisely set out our cobwebs in the most perspicuous places to catch these foolish flies.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: He's in the right; do'st think we retreated hither to beat a bargain for a score of Sheep, or dispute the legality of Votes, and weigh the power of Prerogative and Parliament, and club for concluding Sack, or read the Fathers here, till we grow costive, like those that have worn their suffering Elbows bare, to find a knowledge to perplex'em? A pox on such brain-breaking thoughts; avoid them, and take with me into thy hand a glass of eternal Sack, and prophesie the restauration of senses, and the fall of a Lover from grace, which our dear friend, Mr. Jolly, will prove to whom the Lady Love-all (by Faithful lately departed) sent for the Pearl you wot of.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: But, I hope, he had the grace to keep them.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: No, no; I'me a fool, I.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Was not my Boy here?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: No, we saw him not.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: A pox of the Rogue, he's grown so lasie.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Your Boy is come in just now, and call'd for the key of the back-door, there's women with him.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Oh! that's well, 'tis Wanton; I sent for her, to laugh over the story of the old Lady and her Pearl; where have you been all this while, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I could overtake the Coach, Sir, no sooner.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: The Coach? what Coach?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The Lady Love-alls.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: The Lady Love-alls? why what had you to do with her Coach?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I went to give her the Letter your worship sent her.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: The Letter? what Letter?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: That your worship gave me.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That I writ, at Neds house, to Wanton?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The Letter you gave me, Sir, was directed to the Lady Love-all, and she storm'd like a mad-woman at the reading of it.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Why, thou wilt not beat the Boy for thy own fault? what Letter was it?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: 'Twas enough, only a relation of the Pearl, wherein she finds her self sufficiently abus'd to Wanton.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Now, Gentlemen, you have two to laugh at.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: A pox of fooling, let's resolve what to do, there's no denying, for she has all the particulars under my hand.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: You must resolve of something, for she's coming, and stay'd only till the back-door was open'd.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: How did she know I was here?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Your worship bad me tell her, you would stay here for her.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: How came this mistake?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why, the Devil ought us a shame it seems. You know I went home to give Wanton an accompt how we advanc'd in our design; and when I was writing the superscription, I remember the Boy came in and told me the Lady Love-all pass'd by.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: And so, it seems, you in pure mistake directed your Letter to her.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Well, resolve what you'l do with her, when she comes.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Faith, bear it like men, 'tis but an old Lady lost; lets resolve to defie her, we are sure of our Pearl; but lest we prolong the war, take the first occasion you can all to avoid the room; when she's alone, I'll try whether she'l listen to a composition.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Have you no friends in the close Committee?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I am an Essex man.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Then get some of them to move, it may be voted no Letter.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: I, I; and after 'tis voted no Letter, then vote it false, scandalous and illegal, and that is in it; they have a president for it in the Danish packet, which they took from a foolish fellow, who presuming upon the Law of Nations, came upon an Embassie to the King without an Order, or Pass from both houses.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Heark, I hear her coming.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Sir, I received a Letter, but by what accident I know not; for I believe it was not intended me, though the contents concern me.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Madam, 'tis too late to deny it; is it peace or war you bring? without dispute, if war, I hang out my defiance; if peace, I yield my weapon into your hands.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p:
Are you all unworthy? your whole sex falshood? is it not possible to oblige a man to be loyal? this is such a treachery no age can match; apply your self with youth and wit to gain a Ladies love and friendship only to betray it? was it not enough
you commanded my fortune, but you must wrack my honour too, and instead of being grateful for that charity which still assisted your wants, strive to pay men with injuries, and attempt to make the world believe I pay to lose my fame? and then make me the He smiles .scorn'd subject of your Whores mirth; Base and unworthy, do you smile, false one? I shall find a time for you too, and my vengeance shall find you all.

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: Yea, Sir; and you that had such a ready wit to proclaim my Lady, Whore and me Baud, I hope to see you load a Gallows for it.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Once again, is it peace or war?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Peace? I'll have thy blood first, Dog; where's my Pearl?— You ought to right me, Sir, in this particular; it was to you I She speaks to Wild .sent them.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Madam, I sent not for them.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No more words; I have them, I earn'd them, and you paid them.

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: You are a foul-mouth'd fellow, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Peace, Wench, I scorn their slander, it cannot shake my honour; 'tis too weighty and too fixt for their calumny.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: I'll be sworn for my part on't, I think it is a great honour; I am sure I had as much as I could carry away in ten nights, and yet there was no miss on't.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You? I think so; there's no mark of my work, you see, and yet I came after thee, and brought away loads would have sunk a Sedan-man.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: By this relation she should be a woman of a great fame.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Let that consideration, with her condition, and her age, move some reverence, at least to what she was; Madam, I am sorry I cannot serve you in this particular.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I see all your mean baseness, pursue your scorn; Come, let's go, Wench, I shall find some to right my fame; and though I have lost my opinion, I have gain'd a knowledge how to distinguish of Love hereafter; and I shall scorn you and all your Sex, that have not Soul enough to value a noble Friendship.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, let me speak with you.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: We'll have no whispering; I said it, and I'll maintain it with my sword.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: Sir, there's one without would speak with you?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: With me?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: No, Sir, with Master Wild.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Madam, I'll wait upon you presently.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Madam, I know my Company is displeasing to you, therefore I'll take my leave; Drawer, shew me another Room? The Capt. makes a turn or two, they look at each other, then be goes out.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: Oh Faithfull, Faithfull; I am most miserably abus'd, and can find no way to my Revenge.

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: Madam, I'll give them Rats-bane, and speedily too, ere they can tell; for that Rascall the Captain has a Tongue else, will proclaim you, and undoe your Fame for ever.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: I, I, my Fame, my Fame, Faithfull; and if it were not for mine Honour, (which I have kept unstained to this minute) I would not care.

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: This it is; you will still set your affection upon every young thing; I could but tell you on't.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: Who could have suspected they would have been so false in their Loves to me that have been so faithfull to them.— Honest Friend, where is Master Wild?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: The other Gentlemen carried him away with them?

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: Are they all gone then?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: Yes, by this hand; These Gentlemen are quickly satisfi'd; what an ugly Whore they have got! how she states it! Aside.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: Come, let's go Wench. She offers to go.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: Mistress, who payes the reckoning?

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: What saies he?

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: He askes me, who payes the reckoning?

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: Who payes the reckoning? why, what have we to do with the reckoning?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: Shut the door, Dick, we'll have the reckoning before you go.

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: Why, good-man sawce-box, you will not make my Lady pay for their reckoning, will you?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: My Lady? a pox of her Title, she'd need of something to make her pass.

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: What do you say, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: I say, the Gentlemen paid well for their sport; and I know no reason why we should lose our reckoning.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: What do you take me for, my Friend?

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: In troth, I take you for nothing; but I would be loath to take you for that use I think they made shift with you for.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Madam, this is that Rascally Captains plot.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: Patience, Patience, oh for a bite at the slaves heart. Friend, mistake me not, my name is Love-all, a Lady; send one along with me and you shall have your money.

sp.speaker: Drawer.
sp.p: You must pardon me, Madam, I am but a Servant; if you be a Lady pray sit in an Inner Room, and send home your Woman for the money; The sum is six pounds, and be pleased to remember the Waiters.

sp.speaker: Love-all.
sp.p: Go Faithfull, go fetch the money; Oh Revenge, Revenge: shall I lose my Honour, and have no Revenge.

div.head: ACT. IV. SCEN. I.
div.stage: Enter Wanton, Captain, Careless and Wild.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p:
BY all that a longing Bride hopes for, which I am not, I am better pleas'd with this Revenge then mine own plot, which takes as I could wish; I have so anointed my high Priests with Sack, that he would have confuted Baal's Priest; and now he do's
so slumber in his Ale, and calls to bed already, sweares the Sun is set.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Faith, Wench, her abusing of me made me leave her for the Reckoning.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Yes, faith, they have treated her upsey Whore lain with her, told, and then pawn'd her.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Yes, yes, you are fine things; I wonder Women, can endure you; for me, I expect you worse, and am arm'd for't.

sp.speaker: VVild.
sp.p: Faith let's send and release her, the jest is gone far enough; as I live, I pity her.

sp.speaker: VVant.
sp.p: Pity her? hang her, and rid the Country of her, she is a thing weares out her limbs as fast as her cloathes, one that never goes to bed at all, nor sleepes in a whole skin, but is taken to pieces like a Motion, as if she were too long; she should be hang'd for offring to be a Whore.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: As I live, she is in the right; I peep'd once to see what she did before she went to bed; By this light, her Maids were dissecting her; and when they had done, they brought some of her to bed, and the rest they either pin'd or hung up, and so she lay dismembred till Morning; in which time, her Chamber was strew'd all over, like an Anatomy School.

sp.speaker: VVant.
sp.p: And when she travels any where she is transported with as great a care, and fear of spoiling, as a Juglers Motion, when he removes from Faire to Faire.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: She is a right broken Gamester, who, though she lacks wherewithall to play, yet loves to be looking on.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: He is awake, and calls for you impatiently, he would fain be in Bed, the Company is all gone.

sp.speaker: VVant.
sp.p: Are you instructed?

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Let me alone, I'll warrant you for my part.

sp.speaker: VVant.
sp.p: Farewell then, you are all ready; who playes Master Constable?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I, I; and Ned Jolly the sumner.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Farewell, farewell then.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: It is a delicate wench.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: She has excellent flesh, and a fine face; by this light, we They whisper this .must depose the Captain from his reign here.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I like her shrewdly; I hate a wench that is all Whore and no Company; This is a Comedy all day, and a Faire at night.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I hope to exalt the Parsons horn here.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: And what think you? is it not a sweet sin, this lying with another mans Wife? Wanton above.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Is Jolly come

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No, but he'll be here instantly.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Is he a bed?

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Yes, yes, and he sleepes as if he had been put to bed by his Sexton, with dust to dust, and ashes to ashes.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: And we'll wake him with that shall be as terrible to him as the latter day.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Let him sleep a while that he may be fresh, else the Jest is spoil'd; for it is his sense of his disgrace must work my Ends.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I'll go home then, and get supper ready, and expect you.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Do, Our Scene lies here; Who's there, Jolly?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Are you fitted?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Yes, I have got the Black-fryers Musick; I was fain to stay till the last Act; and who do you think I saw there?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I know not.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Guess.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Prithee, I cannot guess.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Your Aunt and Mistriss Pleasant, and trusty Secret.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: What man?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: The Lovers onely, so close in a Box!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: It will be a match, and there's an End; prithee let them go to't; what is't to Us, let's mind our busines now, and think on them hereafter.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: A pox upon them for a couple of Stauk-hounds; have they killed at last? Why, this is Fools fortune; it would be long enough ere one that has wit got such a wife.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No more of this now; have you borrowed the watchmens Coats?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Yes, and Bills, Beards, and Constables staff, and Lanthorn; and let me alone to fit him, for the Summer; But when this is done I expect my Fee, a Tythe Night at least; Wanton, I will lie with thee for thy Roguery; what are you dumb, you will not refuse me, I hope?

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Not, if I thought thou desiredst it; but I hate to have it desired indifferently, and but so so done neither when 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: I hope you will not disgrace my work, will you?

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Faith, they say thy pleasure lies in thy Tongue; and therefore, Though I do not give thee leave to lie with me, yet I will give thee as good a thing that will please thee as well.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Some Roguery I expected.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: No Faith, I am serious; and because I will please you both, Master Wild shall lie here, and you shall have leave to say you do, which will please you as well.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Faith, and my part is some pleasure, else, I have loved, enjoyed, and told, is mistook.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p:
I, but never to love, seldom enjoy, and always tell? Faugh, it stinks, and stains worse then Shoreditch durt, and women hate and dread men for't; Why, I that am a whore profess'd cannot see you, he digest it, though it be my Profit and Interest. For
to be a private whore in this Town starves in the nest like young Birds when the old one's kil'd.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Excellent Girl, 'tis too true Jolly; your tongue has kept, many a woman honest.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Faith, 'tis a truth, this I shall say, you may all better your pleasures by, if you will observe it; I dare say, the fear of telling keeps more women honest then Bridewell Hemp; And were you wise men, and true Lovers of liberty, now were the time to bring wenching to that perfection no age could ever have hoped; now you may sow such seed of pleasure, you may be prayed for hereafter; Now, in this Age of zeal and Ignorance, would I have you four, in old cloathes, and demure looks, present a Petition to both Houses, and say, you are men touched in Conscience for your share in that wickedness which is known to their worships by the pleasure of Adultery, and desire it may be death, and that a Law may be pass'd to that purpose; How the women will pray for you, and at their own charges rear Statu's in memory of their Benefactors; the young and kind would then haunt your Chambers, Pray, and present you, and Court the Sanguine youth, for the sweet sin secur'd by such a Law; None would lose an Occasion, nor churlishly oppose kind Nature, nor refuse to listen to her summons, when youth and Passion calls for those forbidden sweets; when such security as your lives are at stake, who would fear to trust; with this Law all Oaths and Protestations are cancell'd; Letters and Bawdes would grow useless too; By instinct the Kind will find the Kind; and having one nature become of one mind; Now we lose an Age, to observe and know a mans humour, ere we dare trust him; But get this Law, then 'tis, like and enjoy; and whereas now, with expence of time and Fortune, you may glean some one Mistriss amongst your neighbours wives, you shall reap women whole Armfulls as in the Common field; there is one small Town, wise onely in this Law; and I have heard them say, that know it well, There has been but one Execution this hundred years; yet the same party searched seven years, and could not find an honest woman in the Town.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: An Excellent Plot, let us about it; Inke and Paper, dear Wanton, we will draw the Petition presently.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Will Master Jolly consent too? You must not then, assoon as a handsome woman is named, smile, and stroak your Beard, tell him that is next you, you have layen with her; such a lie is as dangerous as a truth, and 'twere but Justice to have thee hang'd for a sin thou never commitedst, for having defam'd so many women.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: If all those Lyars were hang'd, I believe the scale would weigh down the guilty.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: One Rogue hang'd, for Example, would make a thousand kind Girls: If it take it shall be called my Law, Wanton's Law; Then we may go in Pettycoats again, for women grew imperious and wore the Breeches, only to fright the poor cuckolds, & make the Fools digest their Horns— Are you all ready, shall I open the door?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I'le expect you at my house.

div.stage: [Exit Wild one way, and the rest of the Company another.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Wee'l come, wee'l come.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: So, knock lowder. They knock within, and the Parson discover'd in his Bed and the Baud with him.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Who's there? what would you have?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Here's his Majesties Watch, and Master Constables Worship must come in; We have a warrant from the Lords to search for a Delinquent.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: You come not here, I'le answer your warrant to morrow.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Break open the door.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: I would you durst.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Lord! Dear what shall we do?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Why, sweet, I'le warrant you, art thou not my wife, my Rib, bone of my bone? I'le suffer any thing ere one hair of thee shall be touch'd.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Heark, they break open the door.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: They dare not; why dost thou tremble so? alas, sweet Innocence, how it shakes?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Break open the door.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: I'le complain to the Bishop of this Insolence.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: They come, they come, Lamb.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: No matter sweet; They dare not touch thee; what would He delivers the Warrant .you have Mr. Constable? you are very rude.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Read our Warrant, and our business will excuse us? do you know any such person as you find there?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, but not by this name; such a woman is my wife, and no Lindabrides; we were married to day, and I'le justifie her my wife the next Court day; you have your answer, and may be gone.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: We must take no notice of such Excuses now; if she be your wife, make it appear in Court, and she will be delivered unto you.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: If she be my wife Sir? I have wedded her and Bedded her, what other Ceremonies would you have? Be not afraid, sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Sir, We can do no less then Execute our Warrant; we are but Servants; And, Master Constable, I charge you in the Kings Name to do your Duty; behold the body of the Delinquent.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p:
Touch her that dares; I'le put my Dagger in him, fear
He takes his Dagger..
Here they strive to take her out . nothing, sweet heart; Master Constable you'll repent this Insolence offerd to a man of my Coat.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Help, my dearest, will you let me be hal'd thus?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Villains, what will you do? Murther, Rape.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes, yes, 'tis likely; I look like a Ravisher.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Hold him, and wee'le do well enough with her.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What have we here, an old woman? As they go to pull her out of the Bed, they discover the Baud. When they let him go he turns to her, and holds her in his Arms

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Let me go, slaves and Murtherers.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Let him go.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Do any of you know this woman? this is not she we look'd for.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: No? Rascal, that mistake shall not excuse you.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: It is old Goodman what d'ye call him? his wife.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Hold the Candle, and let's see her face.

div.stage: When they hold the Candle, she lies in his bosom and his Arms about her; She must be as nastily drest as they can dress her; when he sees her he falls into a maze, and shoves her from him.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: What have were here, Adultery? take them both, here will be new matter.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Master Constable, a little Argument will perswade you to believe I am grosly abus'd; sure this do's not look like a piece that a man would sin to enjoy, let that then move your Pity, and care of my Reputation; consider my calling, and do not bring me to a publike shame for what you're sure I am not guilty of, but by plot of some Villains.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Dear, will you disclaim me now?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Oh, Impudence!

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Master Constable, do your duty; take them both away, as you will answer it.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Give him his Cassock, to cover him. They put on his Cassock and her coat, and lead them away.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Why Gentlemen, whither will you carry me?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: To the next Justice, I think it is Master Wild, he is newly come from travel, it will be a good way, Neighbours, to express our Respects to him.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: No faith, Gentlemen, e'ne go the next way to Tybourn, and dispatch the business without Ceremony, for yee'll utterly disgrace me; this is that damn'd Captain; My wife is abroad too, I fear she is of the Plot.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Come, away with'em.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: Whither will they lead us, Dear?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Oh, oh, Impudence! Gentlemen, do not lead us together I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Come, come, lead them together, no Ceremony's; your faults are both alike.

div.head: ACT. IV. SCEN. II.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: YOu had best brag now, and use me like my Lady what'st ye call; But if you do I care not.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Come, y'are a Fool, I'le be a faithful Friend, and make good conditions for thee before thy husband be quit.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: You must do it now or never.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Heark, heark, I hear them— What's the news? Wild sits down with Wanton in his Lap.

div.stage: Enter Captain, Jolly, Watch, Baud and Parson.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: We have brought a Couple of Delinquents before your Worship, they have committed a very foul fault.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: And we have brought the fault along too, that your Worship may see it, you will be the better able to judge of the offenders.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Ha! What do I see? my wife in Master Justices Lap?

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: What has the poor fellow done?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why Madam, he has been taken a Bed with this woman, anothers mans wife.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: In bed with her? and do you raise him to punish him? Master Constable, if you would afflict him, Command them to lie together again; Is not the man mad?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: This is fine Roguery, I find who rules the roast.

sp.speaker: VVild.
sp.p: Well, to the business; you say, he was taken in bed with another mans wife.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes, and't like your Worship.

sp.speaker: VVild.
sp.p: Make his Mittimus to the Hole at New-gate.

sp.speaker: VVant.
sp.p: Sure I have seen this Fellows face.— Friend, have I never seen your face before?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: If I mistake not, I have seen one very like your Ladyships too, she was a Captains cast-whore in the Town. I shall have a time to be reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: How now, Sirrah? are you threatning? away with him.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I'll fetch a stronger Watch, Sir, and return presently.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Do, Master Constable, and give the poor Woman something, and set her free; for I dare say 'twas his wickedness, she lookes like one that ne're thought on such a thing.

sp.speaker: Baud.
sp.p: God bless your Worship, I am innocent; he never left making Love till I consented.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Oh miserable! miserable!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: How now, what's the news here? my honoured Friend, and Master Parson, what makes you here at this time of night? Why I should have thought this a time to have envy'd you for your fair Brides embraces, do you give these favours? are these your Bride-laces? It's a new way. Playes with the cord that bindes his Armes.

sp.speaker: Pars.
