sp.p: Is it new to you?

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: How now Captain?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Wanton, is this your plot to endear your Husband to you?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: No, 'tis thy plot, poor beaten Captain, but I shall be reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes, faith, it was my plot, and I glory in't, to undermine my Machiavell, which so greedily swallowed that sweet bait that had this hook.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: 'Tis well.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: But my anger ends not here. Remember the base language you gave me, Son of a thousand Fathers, Captain of a tame band, and one that got my living by the long staffe-speeches; for which, and thy former Treacheries, I'll ruine thee, Slave; I'll have no more Mercy on thee, then old women on blind puppies; I'll bring you to your Commendations in Latine Epistles again, nor leave thee any thing to live on, no, not Bread, but what thou earn'st by raking Gentlewomens names in Anagrams; and Master Justice, if ever you'll oblige me, stand to me now, that I may procure the whipping of him from the Reverend Bench.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: I am undone.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I can do nothing but Justice, you must excuse me; I shall onely make it appear how fit it is to punish this kind of sin in that Coat in time, and to crush such serpents in the shels.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Mercy, Oh Mercy! They pull him away.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Officers, away with him.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: No Mercy?

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Yes, upon Conditions there may be some Mercy. The Parson lookes very dejected.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: And these they are— let the watch stay in the t'other Roome.— First, your Wife shall have her liberty, and you yours, as she reports of you; and when you bring her with you, you shall be welcome; then you shall not be jealous, that's another point.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That he shall have a Cure for—

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I'll apply something to his Eyes shall cure him of his doubt.

sp.speaker: VVild.
sp.p: Then you shall ask the Captain pardon and your Wife; to him you shall allow half your Parsonage to maintain her; The Deedes are ready within; if you'll sign them, and deliver your Wife to our use, she shall discharge you.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: I submit, Sir, But I hope your Worship will desire no witness to the use of my Wife; The Sumner and the Watch too; I hope your Worship will enjoyn them silence.

sp.speaker: VVant.
sp.p: You shall not need to fear, I'll have a Care of your Credit; She discovers them .call in the Watch; Do you know these Faces?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Ha! abus'd?

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Nay, no flinching, if you do, I betake me to Master Sumner again.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: And I become severe Master Constable in a trice.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: No, no, I submit, and I hope we are all Friends; I'me sure I have the hardest part, to forgive.

sp.speaker: VVant.
sp.p: And I, before all this Company, promise to forget and forgive thee, and am content to take thee again for my dear and mortal Husband, now you are tame; but you must see you do so no more, and give your self to be blind; when it is not fit for you to see; and practise to be deaf; and learn to sleep in time, and find business to call you away when Gentlemen come that would be private.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why so, now things are as they should be; and when you will obey, you shall command: But when you would be imperious, then I betake me to my Constables Staff 'till you subscribe. Cedunt Armis Togae; and if it be false Latine, Parson, you must pardon that too.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: By this hand, I must have my Tythe-night with thee; thou art such a wag; say, when? when wilt thou give me leave? ha!

sp.speaker: VVant.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Never?

sp.speaker: VVant.
sp.p: No, never.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: D' ye hear, I am none of them that work for Charity; either resolve to pay, or I kick down all my Milk again.

sp.speaker: VVant.
sp.p: What would you have?

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Give me leave to lie with you.

sp.speaker: VVant.
sp.p: No indeed.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: No?

sp.speaker: VVant.
sp.p: No; but rather then quarrell, as I said before, I will give you leave to say you have lain with me.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I am of opinion she owes you nothing now, so Mistress Wanton, take your Husband; and to remove all doubts, this night I'll be at the charge of a Wedding supper.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: This is better then Newgate hole yet, Bridewell Hemp, brown bread and whip-cord.

div.head: ACT. IV. SCEN. III.
div.stage: Enter the Widow and Mistress Pleasant, Master Sad, and Master Constant.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: BY my troth, is was a good Play.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: And I am glad I am come home, for I am en'e as weary with this walking; For Gods sake whereabouts do's the pleasure of walking lie? I swear, I have often sought it till I was weary, and yet I could ne're find it. A watch at the Widows door.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: What do these Halberds at your door?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Halberds, where?

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: There, at your Lodging.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Friend, what would those Watch-men have?

sp.speaker: VVatchm.
sp.p: The house is shut up for the sickness this afternoon.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: The sickness?

sp.speaker: VVatchm.
sp.p: Yes forsooth, there's a Coach-man dead full of the Tokens.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Where is the Officer?

sp.speaker: VVatchm.
sp.p: He is gone to seek the Lady of the House, and some other Company that din'd here yesterday, to bring her in, or carry her to the Pest-house.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Ha! What shall we do, Niece?

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: If you please to command our Lodging.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: It will be too much trouble.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Let's go to Love-all's.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Not I, by my Faith; it is scarce for our Credits to let her come to us.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Why? is she naught?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, her Reputation is not good.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: But what shall we do then?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Dare you adventure to oblige us?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Thank you Sir, We'll go to my Nephews at Covent-Garden; he may shift among his acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: It was well thought on, the Piazza is hard by too.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: We'll borrow your Coach thither, and we'll send it you back again straite.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: We'll wait upon you, Madam.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: This accident troubles me; I am heartily sorry for the poor Fellow.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: I am sorry too; but pray, Aunt, let us not forget our selves in our grief; I am not ambitious of a Red-cross upon the door.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Mistress Pleasant is in the right; for if you stay the Officers will put you in.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: We shall trouble you, Sir, for your Coach.

div.head: ACT. IV. SCEN. IV.
div.stage: Enter Parson, Captain, Wild, Wanton, Careless and Jolly.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: I Am reconcil'd; and will no longer be an uncharitable Church-man; I think this sack is a cooler.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What? do's it make you to see your errour?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Yes, and consider my man of war; nor will I again dispute his Letters of Mart, nor call them Passes for Pyrates; I am free.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: And welcome, any thing but anger is sufferable, and all is jest when you laugh; and I will hug thee for abusing me with thy eyes in their scabbards; but when you rail with drawn eyes, red and naked, threatning a Levites second revenge to all that touches your Concubine, then I betake me to a dark-lanthorn, and a Constables-staff, and by help of these Fathers whom I cite I prove my Text, women that are kind ought to be free.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: But Captain, is it not lawful for us Shepherds to reclaim them?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: A meer mistake; for sin like the Sea may be turned out, but will ne're grow less; and though you should drain this Mistress Doll, yet the Whore will find a place, and perhaps overflow some Maid, till then honest; and so you prove the author of a new sin, and the defiler of a pure Temple; therefore I say, while you live, let the Whore alone till she wears out; nor is it safe to vamp them, as you shall find, read Ball the first and the second.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No more discourse. Strike up Fidlers.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: See, who's that knocks?

div.stage: A Country-dance. When they are merry, singing Catches and drinking healths, the Wid. Mrs. Pleas. and the two Lovers knock at the door.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, 'tis Mistress Pleasant, and the two Gentlemen that din'd there to day.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: My Aunt, and Mistress Pleasant.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: What a pox makes them abroad at this time of night?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: It may be, they have been a wenching.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, they were upon alighting out of the Coach when I came up.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Quickly, Mrs. Wanton, you and your husband to bed, there's the Key; Mr. Parson, you know the way to the old Chamber, and to it quickly, all is friends now.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Sweet heart, we'l steal away.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: The Devil on them, they have spoyld our mirth.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Jack, get you and your company down the back-way into the Kitchin, and stay there till we see what this Visit means.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Means! What should it mean? it is nothing but the mischievous Nature all honest Women are endu'd with, and naturally given to spoyl sport: I wonder what Fart blew them hither to night.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Nay, have a little patience, Captain; you and Mr. Jolly must sit quietly a while within, till we know the cause.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: It is but deferring our mirth for an hour, or so. Servant. Sir, here's my Lady.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Quickly remove those things there: Captain, step in there.—

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nephew, do you not wonder to see me here, at this time of night?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I know it is not ordinary, therefore I believe 'tis some designe: what is it, Mrs. Pleasant? Shall I make one?

sp.speaker: Pleasant.
sp.p: As I live, Sir, pure necessity; neither mirth nor kindness hath begot this Visit.

sp.speaker: Carless.
sp.p: What, is your Coach broke?

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Faith, Nephew, the truth is, the Sickness is in my house, and my Coach-man dy'd since Dinner.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: The Sickness?

sp.speaker: Pleasant.
sp.p: I, as I live, we have been walking since the Play; and when we came home we found the Watch at the door, and the house shut up.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: And a Constable gone in search of all those that dined there to day, with order to furnish us lodgings in the Pest-house.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Are you not afraid to receive us?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: As I live, the accident troubles me; and I am sorry such a misfortune should beget me this favour; and I could wish my self free from the honour, if the cause were removed too.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: As I live, Mr. Wild, I must have been forc'd to have lain with my servant to night, if you had not received me.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: If I thought so, I would carry you out in my arms, I am so much Mr. Constant's friend.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: But are you more his friend then mine, Mr. Wild?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No, but I presume by this he has gain'd so much interest as he would not be very displeasing to you.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Oh! your humble servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: If I had had a mind to that lodging, I had ne're come hither; for when I have a mind to it, I'll marry without dispute; for I fear no body so much as a husband; and when I can conquer that doubt, I'll marry at a minutes warning.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No dispute now, can you furnish us with a couple of Beds?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And have you er'e a woman in the house?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: My Sisters Maid is here.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Madam, if you resolve to do us this honour, you shall find clean linen, and your Beds quickly ready.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But where will my Nephew and you, Sir, lie to night?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, we have acquaintance enough in the Town.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Well, Sir, we'l accept this courtesie; and when you come into Suffolk you shall command my house.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Prithee call Bess, and bid her bring sheets to make the Bed; I'll go and fetch in a Pallet, 'tis as good a Bed as the other, and if you will stay the removing, we'l set up a Bed-stead.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: No, a Pallet, pray; but what shall we do for night cloathes, Aunt?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Why, what are those you bought my Sisters?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Is not that Linen gone yet?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: No faith, Madam, his man forgot it, till the Carriers were gone last week.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Will that serve?

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Yes, yes, pray do us the favour to let us have it, 'tis but washing of't again.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Nay, if it will serve, discourse no more; I'll fetch the bundle; and prithee fetch the Combs and Looking glasses I bought the other day; for other necessaries that want a name the wench shall furnish you with.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay, but where is she, Nephew?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I'll call her, if she be not gone to Bed; it is an ignorant young thing, I am to send her to my Sisters in the Country; I have had such ado to put her in the Fashion.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: What Country is she? Prithee, Mr. Wild, let's see her.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I'll call her down.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Madam, now we see y'are safe we'l kiss your hands, and wait upon you to morrow.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: It must be early then, Sir; for I shall borrow my Nephews Coach, and be gone betimes into the Country to take a little fresh Air, and prevent the search.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, be pleased to command ours.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: No, Sir, I humbly thank you; my Nephew's will hold our company.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Your humble servant, Mistress Pleasant.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Your servant, Madam.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Good night, Mr. Constant.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Sir, you'l excuse us, we have no body here to light you down.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Madam, I am here your servant as much as those that wear your Livery; and this house holds no other; we can be civil, Madam, as well as extravagant.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Your humble servant, Mr. Careless.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Gentlemen, if you'l wait on my Lady to her Chamber, then I'll wait upon you down.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: You oblige us, Sir.

div.head: ACT. IV. SCEN. V.
div.stage: Enter Wild, Captain, Wanton, Parson and Jolly.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: THe Plague?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: The Plague; As I live, and all my relation is truth, every syllable; But, Mrs. Wanton, now must you play your master-piece; be sure to blush, and appear but simple enough, and all is well; thou wilt pass for as arrant a Chamber-maid as any is in the Parish.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Hum! new Plots?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Let me put on a Petti-coat and a Muffler, and I'll so Chamber-maid it, and be so diligent with the clean Smock and the Chamber-pot: now would I give all the Shooes in my Shop to lie with 'em both.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Let me alone to fit them, I can make a scurvey Curt'sie naturally; remember, I am an Essex woman, if they ask.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Come, come quickly, take those Sweet-meats; bring the great Cake and Knife, and Napkins, for they have not supp'd; and Captain, make some Lemonade, and send it by the Boy to my Chamber; and do you hear, Jolly, you must stay till we come, for we must lie with you to night.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: We'l stay, but make haste then.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: And bring our Cloaks and Swords out with you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I will, I will; but be quiet all.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Mr. Wild, I hope there is no Plot in this.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: There's no jealousie, Mr. Parson; 'tis all serious upon my life.

div.head: ACT. IV. SCEN. VI.
div.stage: The Tyring-Room, Curtains drawn, and they discourse, his Chamber, two Beds, two Tables, Looking-glasses, Night-cloathes, Waste-coats, Sweet-bags, Sweet-meats and Wine, Wanton drest like a Chamber-maid; all above if the Scene can be so order'd.
Enter Widow and Mrs. Pleasant, Wild and Careless; the Widow and Mrs. Pleasant Salute Wanton.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: FAith, Aunt, 'tis the first time I have had the honour to see you in my house; and as a stranger I must salute you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: As I live, Nephew, I'me asham'd to put you to this trouble.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: It is an obligation.— Mrs. Pleasant, I know you have not supp'd; I pray you be pleas'd to taste these Sweet-meats, they are of Salls doing; but I understand not Sweet-meats, the wine I'll answer for; and, in a word, you are welcome: You are Patrona, and we your slaves.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Good rest, and a pleasing dream, your humble servant wishes you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Good night, Nephew; good night, Mr. Careless.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Good night, Mr. Careless; your humble servant, Mr. Wild.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why I, here are men have some wit; By this good night, had we lain at my servants, we should have found the lac'd Cap and Slippers that have been entail'd upon the Family these five descents, advanc'd upon the Cup-boards-head instead of Plate. They sit down to undress them.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: They are a couple of the readiest youths too; how they run and do all things with a thought! I love him for sending his Sister, a pretty wench.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pray, let's go to bed; I am weary.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: You will not go to bed with all those windows open; sweet heart, prithee shut them, and bring me hither;— Dost understand me? As I live, 'tis a great while since I went to the Play.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: It has been one of the longest days; a year of them would be an Age.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Oh, do you grow weary; you'l break your Covenant ere the year go out.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Prithee, shut the windows, and come pin up my hair. The Curtains are closed.

div.head: ACT. IV. SCEN. VII.
div.stage: Enter Wild, Jolly, Careless, Captain and Parson, and Fidlers, and one with a Torch, with their Cloaks and their Swords, putting them on. Enter Wilds man.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: SEE you wait diligently, and let them want nothing they call for; come shall we go? 'tis very late.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: But how do's VVanton carry it?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: They saluted her; and Mrs. Pleasant swore you might see the Country-simplicity in her Face.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: A pox upon her, crafty Gypsie.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why, art not thou glad to see she can be honest when she will?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: I'll shew you all a Trick, for her, within these few days, or I'll miss my aim.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Come, let's go. They all offer to go.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I have a mind to stay till Wanton comes.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Stay a little then, for 'twill not be long ere they be a Bed.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I hear VVanton's voice.

sp.speaker: VVild.
sp.p: Are they a Bed?

sp.speaker: VVant.
sp.p: Yes, and have so admir'd you, and Mr. Careless, and abus'd the Lovers; well, Gentlemen, you are the wits of the time; but if I might counsel, well they might lye alone this night; but it should go hard if I lay not with one of them within a moneth.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Were they so taken with their lodging?

sp.speaker: VVant.
sp.p:
All that can be said they said, you are the friendliest men, the readi'st men, the handsom'st men that had wit; and could tell when to be civil, and when to be wild; and Mrs. (what's her
name) the Younger, asked why Mr. VVild did not go a wooing to some rich Heir; upon her conscience, she said, you would speed.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Well, well, there's a time for all things; come let's go.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Take a light.— Good night, VVanton. They offer to depart.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: D'ye hear, d'ye hear; let me speak with you.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: What's the business? They all come back again.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I cannot get hence this night: but your good angels hang at my heels; and if I can prevail, you shall stay.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: What to do?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What to do? why I'll be hang'd if all this Company do not guess.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Prithee, what should we stay for?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: For the widow, and her Neice; are they worth the watching for a night?

sp.speaker: VVild.
sp.p: Yes, certainly.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Then take my counsel, and let me give it out y'are married, you have new cloaths come home this morning, and ther's that you spoke of I'll fetch from the Taylors, and here's a Parson shall rather give them his living, then stay for a License; the Fidlers too are ready to salute 'em.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: But if they refuse?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Which, upon my conscience, they will.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: As you hope, else you are laugh'd at for missing the widow: Ned, follow my counsel, appear at her Chamber window in thy Shirt, and salute all that passes by; let me alone to give it out, and invite Company and provide dinner; then when the business is known, and I have presented all your friends at Court with Ribbands, she must consent, or her honour is lost, if you have but the grace to swear it, and keep your own counsel.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: By this hand, he has reason; and I'll undertake the widow.

sp.speaker: VVild.
sp.p: It will incense them, and precipitate the business which is in a fair way now; and if they have wit, they must hate us for such a treachery.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: If they have wit they will love you; beside, if it come to that, we two will swear we saw you married, and the Parson shall be sworn he did it:— Priest, will you not swear?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Yes, any thing; what is't, Captain?

sp.speaker: VVild.
sp.p: If this jest could do it, yet 'tis base to gain a wife so poorly; she came hither too for sanctuary; it would be an uncivil and an unhospitable thing, and look as if I had not merit enough to get a wife without stealing her from her self; then, 'tis in mine own house.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: The better; nay, now I think on't, why came she hither? how do you know the Plague is there? all was well at dinner; I'll be hang'd if it be not a Plot; the Lovers too whom you abus'd at dinner, are joyn'd with them; a trick, a meer trick of wit to abuse us; and to morrow when the Birds are flewn, they'l laugh at you, and say, Two Country Ladies put themselves naked into the hands of three travel'd City-wits, and they durst not lay hold on them.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: A pox upon these Niceties.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: If they have not some design upon you hang me, why did they talk so freely before me else?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Let's but try, we are not now to begin to make the world talk; nor is it a new thing to them to hear we are mad fellows.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: If you get them, are they worth having?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Having? yes.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: If you miss them the Jest is good; Prithee, Ned, let me prevail, 'tis but a mad trick.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: If we would, how shall we get into the Chamber?

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Let me alone for that; I'le put on my country simplicity, and carry in a Chamber pot; then under Pretence of bolting the back door I'le open it, and yet I grudge them the sport so honestly; for you wenchers make the best husbands; after you are once married, one never see's you.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I warrant thee wench.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: No faith, I have observ'd it, they are still the doting'st husbands, and then retreat and become Justices of the Peace, and none so violent upon the Bench, as they, against us poor sinners; yet I'le do it, for upon my Conscience the young Gentlewoman will fall upon her back, and thank me.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Away, go then, and leave your fooling, and in the Morning, Ned, get in, and plead naked with your hands in the bed.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: And if they cry, put your lips in their mouths, and stop them.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why look you, you have the Authority of the Church too.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Well, I am now resolv'd; go you about your part, and make the Report strong.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: And d'ye here? be sure you set the Cook at work, that if we miss we may have a good Dinner, and good wine, to drink down our grief.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Miss? I warrant thee thrive.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Nay, if I knock not down the VVidow, geld me, and come out to morrow compleat Uncle, and salute the Company, with, you are well-come Gentlemen, and good morrow Nephew Ned.

sp.speaker: VVild.
sp.p: Uncle Tom, good morrow, Uncle Tom.

sp.speaker: VVant.
sp.p: All's done, the door is open, and they're as still as Childrens thoughts; 'tis time you made you ready, which is, to put off your breeches, for 'tis almost day; and take my Councel, be sure to offer force enough, the less reason will serve; Especially you, Master VVild, do not put a may'd to the pain of saying, I.

sp.speaker: VVild.
sp.p: I warrant thee, wench; let me alone.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Wee'll in, and undress us, and come again; for we must go in at the back door.

sp.speaker: VVild.
sp.p: I'le meet you, is the Captain gone?

sp.speaker: VVant.
sp.p: Yes, yes, hee's gone.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p:
Come Master Parson, let us see the Cook in Readiness, where are the Fidlers? what will become of our Plot? for the
Coach-man; Master Sadd and his friend will stink of their jest if this thrive.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: They have slept all night, on purpose, to play all day.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: When the Ribbands and Poynts come from the Exchange, pray see the Fidlers have some, the Rogues will play so out of tune all day else, they will spoil the dancing if the plot do take.

div.stage: Enter Wild, and Careless, in their Shirts, with drawers under; Night-gowns on, and in Slippers.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Let's see them in the Chamber first, and then I shall go with some heart about the business; so, so, creep close and quietly; you know the way, the widow lies in the high bed, and the Pallet is next the door.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p:
Must we creep?
They kneel at the door to go in.
She shakes her Coats over 'em.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Yes, Yes, down upon your knees, always, till you get a woman, and then stand up for the Cause; stay let me shake my smock over you for luck sake.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Why so, I warrant you thrive.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: A pox take you, I'll pare your nails when I get you from this place once.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Sweet heart, sweet heart, off with your shooe.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: I, with all my heart, there's an old shooe after you; would I gave all in my shop the rest were furnish'd with wives too.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Parson, the Sun is rising, go send in the Fidlers, and set the Cook on work, let him chap soundly.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: I have a tythe Pig at home, I'll e'ne sacrifice it to the Wedding.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: They will find them in good Posture, they may take Privy marks if they please; for they said it was so hot they could endure no cloathes, and my simplicity was so diligent to lay them naked, and with such 'twists and turns fastned them to the feet, I'll answer for't, they finde not the way into them in an hour.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Why then they may pull up their Smocks, and hide their faces?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Master Jolly, there was one without would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Who was it?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: It is the Lady that talks so well.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: They say indeed she has an Excellent Tongue, I would she had chang'd it for a face; 'tis she that has been handsome.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Who? not the Poetess we met at Master Sadds?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Yes, the same.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Sure shee's mad.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Prithee tell her I am gone to bed.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I have done as well Sir; I told her Mistris Wanton was here, at which discreetly, being touch'd with the guilt of her Face, she threw out a Curse or two and retreated.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Who is this you speak of, I will know who 'tis.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Why 'tis she that married the Genoway Merchant; they conzen'd one another.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Who? Pegg Driver, Bewgle Eyes?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: The same, the same.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Why she is ugly now?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Yes, but I have known her, by this hand, as fine a wench as ever sinn'd in Town or Suburbs; when I knew her first, she was the Original of all the wayn-Scote Chambermaids, with Brooms, and barefoot Madams, you see sold at Temple-Bar, and the Exchange.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Ah! th'art a Divel; how could'st thou find in thy heart to abuse her so? Thou lov'st Antiquities too; The very memory that she had been handsome should have pleaded something.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Was handsome signifies nothing to me.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: But shee's a wit, and a wench of an Excellent Discourse.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: And as good company as any's i'th Town.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Company? for whom? Leather-Ears, his Majesty of Newgate watch? There her story will do well, while they louse themselves.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Well, you are curious now, but the time was, when you have skipp'd for a kiss.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Prithee, Parson, no more of wit, and was handsome, but He kisses Wanton .let us keep to this Text— and with joy think upon thy little Wanton here, that's kind, soft, sweet and sound; These are Epithetes for a Mistris; Nor is there any Elegancy in a woman like it; give me such a naked Scence, to study Night and Day; I care not for her Tongue, so her face be good; A whore dres't in verse, and set speeches, tempts me no more to that sweet sin, then the Statute of whipping can keep me from it; This thing we talk'd on, which retains nothing but the name of what she was, is not onely Poetical in her discourse, but her Tears and her Love, her health, nay her Pleasure, were all Fictions, and had scarce any live-flesh about her till I administred.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Indeed 'tis time she sat out, and gave others leave to play; for a Reveren'd whore is an unseemly sight; besides it makes the sin malicious, which is but venial else.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Sure, hee'le make a case of Conscience on't; you should do well (sweet heart) to recommend her Case to your Brethren that attend the Committee of Affection, that they may order her to be sound and young again, for the good of the Commonwealth.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: OH, are you ready? are you ready?

sp.speaker: Fidlers.
sp.p: Yes, and't like your worship.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: And did you bid the Cook chop Lustily, and make a Noise?

sp.speaker: Fidlers.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, hee's at it.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: I hear the Captain.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Have you brought Clothes and Ribbands?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes, yes, all is ready; did you hear them squeak yet?

sp.speaker: VVant.
sp.p: No, by this light; I think, 'tis an appointment, and we have been all abus'd.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Give the Fidlers their Ribbands, and carry the rest in; Mistris VVanton, you must play my Ladys Woman to day, and Mince it to all that come, and hold up your head finely when they kiss you, and take heed of swearing when you are angry, and pledging whole cups when they drink to you.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: I'le warrant you, for my part.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Go get you in then, and let your husband dip the Rosemary.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Is all ready?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: All, all, some of the Company are below already, I have so blown it about, one Porter is gone to the Exchange, to invite Master Wild's Merchant to his Wedding, and, by the way to bid two or three Fruiterers to send in Fruit for such a Wedding, another in my Ladies name to Sall's, for sweet meats; I swore at Bradborn in his Shop my self, that I wonder'd he would disappoint Master Wild for his Points, and having so long warning; He protested 'twas not his fault, but they were ready, and he would send John with them presently; One of the Watermen is gone to the Mellon Garden, the other to Cooks at the Bear, for some Bottles of his best Wine, and thence to Gracious-street, to the Poulterers, and all with directions to send in Provisions for Master Wild's Wedding; and who should I meet at Door, but Apricock Tom, and Mary, waiting to speak with her young Master; they came to beg that they might serve the Feast; I promis'd them they should, if they would cry it up and down the Town, to bring Company; for Master Wild was resolved to keep open house.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Why then here will be witnesses enough.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: But who should I meet at the corner of the Piazza, but Joseph Taylor; he tells me, there's a new Play at the Fryers to day, and I have bespoke a Box for Master Wild and his Bride.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: And did not he wonder to hear he was married?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes; but I told him, 'twas a Match his Aunt made for him, when he was abroad.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: And I have spread it sufficiently at Court, by sending to borrow Plate for such a Wedding.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: There's half a dozen Coach fulls of Company lighted; they call for the Bride-Laces and Points.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Let the Fidlers play then, and bid God give them joy, by the name of my Lady Careless and Mistriss Wild.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.p: Where shall we play, Sir?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Come with us, wee'le shew you the window.

div.head: ACT. V. SCEN. II.
div.stage: The Fidlers play in the Tyring Room, and the Stage Curtains are Drawn, and discover a Chamber, as it was, with two Beds and the Ladies asleep in them; Master Wild being at Mistris Pleasant's Bed-side, and Master Careless at the Widow's; The Musick awakes the Widow.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: NIece, Niece, Niece Pleasant.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Ha! I hear you, I hear you, what would you have? She opens the Curtain and calls her, she is under a Canopy.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Do you not hear the Fidlers?

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Yes, yes, but you have wak'd me from the finest dream.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: A dream, what was't? some knavery.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Why, I know not, but 'twas merry, e'ne as pleasing as some sins; well, I'le lie no more in a mans bed, for fear I lose more then I get.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Heark, that's a new Tune.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Yes, and they play it well; This is your Jaunty Nephew; I would he had less of the Father in him, I'de venture to dream out my dream with him; In my conscience hee's worth a dozen of my dull Servant, that's such a troublesome visitant, without any kind of conveniency.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I, I, so are all of that kind; give me your Subject Lover; Those you call Servants are but troubles, I confess.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: What is the Difference, pray, betwixt a Subject, and a Servant Lover?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why, one I have absolute Power over, the other's at large; Your Servant Lovers are those take Mistresses upon tryal, scarce give them a Quarters warning before they are gone.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Why, what do your Subject Lovers do? I am so sleepy.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Do? All things for nothing; then they are the diligent'st and the humblest things a Woman can employ; Nay, I ha' seen of them tame, and run loose about a house; I had one once, by this light, he would fetch and Carry, go back, seek out, he would do any thing; I think some Faulconer bred him.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: By my Troth, I am of your mind.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: He would come over, for all my Friends; but it was the dogged'st thing to my enemies, he would sit upon's tail before them, and frown, like John a Napes when the Pope is nam'd; he heard me once praise my little Spanniel Bitch Smut for waiting, and hang me if I stirr'd for seven years after, but I found him lying at my door.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: And what became of him?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Faith, when I married he forsook me; I was advis'd since, that if I would ha' spit in's mouth sometimes he would have stay'd.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p:
That was cheap, But 'tis no certain way; for 'tis a generall opinion, that marriage is one of the certain'st cures for Love that one can apply to a man that is sick of the sighings; yet if you were to live about this Town still, such a Fool would do you a
world of service; I'me sure Secret will miss him, and would alwayes take such a care of her ha's sav'd her a hundred walkes for Hoods and Masques.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Yes, and I was certain of the earliest Fruits and Flowers that the Spring afforded.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: By my troth, 'twas foolishly done to part with him; a few crums of your affection would have satisfied him, poor thing.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Thou art in the right; in this Town there's no living without 'em; they do more service in a house for nothing, then a pair of those, what d' ye call ems', those he waiting-women, Beasts, that Custome impose upon Ladies.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Is there none of them to be had now, think you? I'de feign get a tame one, to carry down into the Country.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Faith, I know but one breed of them about the Town that's right, and that's at the Court; The Lady that has them brings 'em all up by hand; she breedes some of them from very puppies; there's another wit too in the Town that has of them; but hers will not do so many tricks; good sullen diligent waiters those are which she breedes, but not half so serviceable.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: How do's she do it? is there not a trick in't?

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Onely patience, but she has a heavy hand with 'em (they say) at first, and many of them miscarry; she governes them with signes, and by the Eye, as Bank's breedes his Horse; there are some too that arrive at writing, and those are the right breed, for they commonly betake themselves to Poetry; and if you could light on one of them, 'twere worth your money; for 'tis but using of him ill, and praysing his verses sometimes, and you are sure of him for ever.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: But do they never grow surly, Aunt?

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Not, if you keep them from raw flesh, for they are a kind of Lyon-lovers; and if they once taste the sweet of it, they'll turn to their kind.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Lord, Aunt, there will be no going without one this Summer into the Country; pray let's enquire for one; either a he one to entertain us, or a she one to tell us the story of her Love; 'tis excellent to bed-ward, and makes one as drowsie as Prayers.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Faith, Niece, this Parliament has so destroy'd 'em, and the Platonick Humour, that 'tis uncertain whether we shall get one or no; your leading Members in the lower House have so cow'd the Ladies, that they have no leisure to breed any of late; Their whole endeavours are spent now in feasting, and winning close Committee-men, a rugged kind of sullen Fellows, with implacable stomacks and hard hearts, that make the gay things court and observe them, as much as the foolish Lovers use to do; Yet I think I know one she-Lover, but she is smitten in years o'th wrong side of forty; I am certain she is poor too; and in this lean Age for Courtiers, she perhaps would be glad to run this Summer in our Park.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Dear Aunt, let us have her; has she been famous? has she good Tales, think you, of Knights? such as have been false or true to Love, no matter which.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: She cannot want cause to curse the Sex; handsome, witty, well born, and poor in Court, cannot want the experience how false young men can be; Her Beauty has had the highest fame; and those Eyes that weep now unpitied have had their Envy, and a dazling Power.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: And that Tongue, I warrant you, which now growes hoarse with flattering the great Law-breakers, once gave Law to Princes; was it not so Aunt? Lord, shall I die without begetting one story?

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Penthesilea, nor all the cloven Knights the Poets treat of, yclad in mightiest Petticoats, did her excell for gallant deeds; and, with her Honour, still preserv'd her Freedom; My Brother lov'd her; and I have heard him swear, Minerva might have own'd her Language; An Eye like Pallas, Juno's wrists, a Venus for shape, and a Mind chaste as Diana, but not so rough; never uncivilly Cruel, nor faulty kind to any; no vanity, that sees more then Lovers pay, nor blind to a gallant Passion; Her Maxim was, he that could Love, and tell her so handsomely, was better Company, but not a better Lover then a silent Man; Thus, all Passions found her Civility, and she a value from all her Lovers. But alass, Niece, this was (which is a sad word) was handsome, and was beloved, are abhorred sounds in Womens ears. The Fidlers play again.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Hark, the Fidlers are merry still; will not Secret have the wit to find us this morning, think you?

sp.speaker: Fidlers.
sp.p: God give you joy, Master Careless; God give your Ladyship joy, my Lady VVild.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: What did the Fellow say? God give me joy?

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: As I live, I think so.

sp.speaker: Fidlers.
sp.p: God give you joy, Mistress Pleasant Wild.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: This is my Nephew, I smell him in this knavery.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Why did they give me joy by the name of Mistress VVild? I shall pay dear for a nights lodging if that be so, especially lying All the company confused without, and bid God give them joy .alone; By this light, there is some knavery afoot.

sp.speaker: Jolly.
sp.p: Rise, rise, for shame, the year's afore you.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why, Ned Wild, why Tom, will you not rise and let's in? what, is it not enough to steal your wedding over night, but lock your selves up in the morning too? All your Friends stay for points here, and kisses from the Brides.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: A little Patience, you'll give us leave to dress us? The Women squeeke when they speak.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Why, what's a Clock, Captain?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: It's late.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Faith, so it was before we slept.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why, Nephew, what means this rudeness? As I live, I'll fall out with you. This is no jest.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No, as I live, Aunt. We are in earnest; but my part lies here, and there's a Gentleman will do his best to satisfie you; They catch the Women in their Armes .and sweet Mistress Pleasant, I know you have so much wit as to perceive this business cannot be remedied by denials; here we are, as you see, naked, and thus have saluted hundreds at the window that past by, and gave us joy this morning.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Joy, of what? what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Madam, this is visible, and you may coy it, and refuse to call me Husband; But I am resolved to call you Wise, and such Careless kisses the Widow .proofs I'll bring as shall not be denyed.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Promise your self that; see whether your fine wits can make it good; you will not be uncivil?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Not a hair but what you give, and that was in the Contract before we undertook it; for any Man may force a Womans Body, but we have laid we will force your Mind.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: But that needs not, for we know by your discourse last night and this morning, we are Men you have no aversion to; and I believe, if we had taken time and wooed hard, this would have come a course; but we had rather win you by wit, because you defi'd us.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, if it succeed.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: And, for my part, but for the jest of winning you, and this way, not ten joynters should have made me marry?

sp.speaker: VVid,
sp.p: This is a new way of wooing.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: 'Tis so, Madam; but we have not laid our plot so weakly (though it were sudden) to leave it in any bodies power but our own to hinder it.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Do you think so?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: We are secure enough, if we can be true to our selves.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Yet we submit in the midst of our strength, and beg you will not wilfully spoile a good jest by refusing us. By this hand, we are both sound, and we'll be strangely honest, and never in ill humours, but live as merry as the Maids, and divide the year between the Town and the Country; What say you, is't a Match? Your bed is big enough for two, and my meat will not cost you much; I'll promise nothing but one heart, one purse betwixt us, and a whole dozen of boyes, is't a bargain?

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Not, if I can hinder it, as I live.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Faith, Mistress Pleasant, he hath spoken nothing but reason, and I'll do my best to make it good; Come faith, teach my Aunt what to do, and let me strike the bargain upon your Lips.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: No, Sir, not to be half a Queen; if we should yield now your wit would dominere for ever; and still in all disputes (though never so much reason on our side) this shall be urged as an Argument of your Master wit to confute us; I am of your Aunts mind, Sir; and if I can hinder it, it shall be no match.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Why then know, it is not in your Powers to prevent it.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why, we are not married yet.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: No, 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: By this good light then I'll be dumb for ever hereafter, lest I light upon the words of Marriage by chance.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: 'Tis hard, when our own Acts cannot be in our own power, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: The plot is only known to four, the Minister and two that stood for Fathers, and a simple Country Maid that waited upon you last night, which playes your Chamber-maids part.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: And what will all these do?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Why, the two friends will swear, they gave you; the Parson will swear, he married you; and the wench will swear, she put us to bed.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Have you men to swear we are married?

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: And a Parson to swear he did it?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: And a wench that will swear, she put us to Bed?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Yes, By this good light, and witness of reputation.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Dare they or you look us in the face, and swear this?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Yes faith, and all but those four know no other but really it is so; and you may deny it, but I'll make Mr. Constable put you to bed, with this proof, at night.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Pray, let's see these witnesses.

sp.speaker: VVild.
sp.p: Call in the four only.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Well, this shall be a warning to me; I say nothing, but if ever I lye from home again.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I'll lye with you.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: 'Tis well; I dare say, we are the first women (if this take) that ever were stollen against their wills.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: I'll go call the Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: I that have refus'd a fellow that lov'd me these seven years, and would have put off his hat, and thanked me to come to bed, to be beaten with watch-mens staves into anothers; For by this good light, for ought that I perceive, there's no keeping these out at night.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: And unless we consent to be their wives, to day, M. Justice will make us their whores at night: oh, oh, what would not I give to come off! not that I mislike them, but I hate they should get us thus.

div.stage: Enter Wild, Jolly, Captain, Careless, Parson, Wanton, with Rose-mary in their hands, and Points in their Hats.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Follow.— Will not you two swear we were married last night?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Capt. Yes, By this light, will we.

sp.speaker: VVild.
sp.p: Will not you swear you married us?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Yea, verily.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: And come hither, pretty one, will not you swear you left us all a bed last night, and pleas'd?

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Yes forsooth; I'll swear any thing your worship shall appoint me.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: But, Gentlemen, have you no shame, no conscience; will you swear false, for sport?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: By this light, I'll swear, if it be but to vex you: Remember you refus'd me, [That is contrary to Covenants though with my brace of Lovers; what will they do with their Coach-mans Speaks these words, aside .plot? but 'tis no matter, I have my ends; and so they are couzen'd I care not who does it.]

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: And, faith, Madam, I have sworn many times false, to no purpose; and I should take it ill, if it were mine own case, to have a friend refuse me an Oath upon such an occasion.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: And are you all of one mind?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Verily we will all swear.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Will you verily? what shall we do, Aunt? Pleas. laughs.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Do you laugh? By this light, I am heartily angry.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Why, As I live, let's marry them, Aunt, and be reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Marry, where's the Parson?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Here, here, M. Parson, come and do your Office.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: That fellow? No, by my troth, let's be honestly joyn'd, for lucks sake, we know not how soon we may part.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: What shall she do for a Parson? Captain, you must run and fetch one.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes, yes; but methinks this might serve turn; By this hand, he's a Marshal, and a Case, by Sire and Dam; pray try him, By this light, he comes of the best preaching kind in Essex.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Not I, As I live, that were a blessing in the Devils name.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: A pox on your wedding; give me my wife and let me be gone.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Nay, nay, no choler, Parson; the Ladies do not like the colour of your Beard.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: No, no, fetch another, and let them escape with that trick, then they'l jeer your beards blew, y'faith.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: By this hand, he's in the right; either this Parson, or take one anothers words; to Bed now, and marry when we rise.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: As I live, you come not here till you are married; I have been no body's whore yet, and I will not begin with my husband.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Will you kiss upon the bargain, and promise before these witnesses not to spoil our jest, but rise and go to Church.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: And what will M. Constant and M. Sadd say?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why, I'll run and invite them to the wedding; and you shall see them expire in their own Garters.

sp.speaker: Joll,
sp.p: No, no, ne're fear't, their jest is only spoil'd.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Their jest, what jest?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Faith, now you shall know it, and the whole Plot: In the first place, your Coach-man is well, whose death, we, by the help of Secret, contriv'd, thinking by that trick to prevent this danger, and carry you out of Town.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: But had they this Plot?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Yes faith, and see how it thrives; they'l fret like carted Bauds when they hear this news.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Why, Aunt; would you have thought M. Sadd a Plotter? well, 'tis some comfort we have them to laugh at.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Nay faith, then, Gentlemen, give us leave to rise, and I'll take my venture, if it be but for a revenge on them.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Gentlemen, bear witness.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Come, come away, I'll get the points; I'me glad the Coach-man's well, the Rogue had like to have spoild our Comedy.

div.head: ACT. V. SCEN. III.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Love-all, Master Sadd, and Constant, undress'd and buttoning themselves as they go.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: MArried?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: And to them?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I, married, if you prevent it not; catch'd with a trick, an old stale trick; I have seen a Ballad on't.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: We shall go neer to prevent 'em.— Boy, My Sword.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Whither so fast?

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: You guess.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: If you mean the wedding, you come too late.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Why, are they married?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No, but lustily promised.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: We may come time enough to be reveng'd though.—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Upon whom? your selves, for you are only guilty: who carried them thither last night? who laid the Plot for the Coachman?

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Why, do they know it?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Well, you'l find the Poet a Rogue, 'tis he that has betray'd you; and if you'le take my counsel, be reveng'd upon him.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Nay, we were told he did not love us.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: By my life, you wrong him; upon my knowledge the Poet meant you should have them.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Why, who had the power to hinder then?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I know not where the fault lies directly; they say, the wits of the Town would not consent to't, they claim a right in the Ladies, as Orphan-wits.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: The wits! hang 'em in their strong lines.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why I, such a clinch as that has undone you; and upon my knowledge 'twere enough to hinder your next match.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Why, what have they to do with us?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I know not what you have done to disoblige them; but they crost it; there was amongst 'em too a pair of she-wits, something stricken in years; they grew in fury at the mention of it, and concluded you both with an authority out of a modern Author; besides 'tis said, you run naturally into the six-peny Room and steal sayings, and a discourse more then your peny-worth of jests, every Term; why, just now, you spit out one jest stollen from a poor Play, that has but two more in five Acts; what conscience is there in't, knowing how dear we pay Poets for our Plays?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: 'Twas, Madam, with the ill face, one of those whom you refus'd to salute the other day, at Chipps house; a Chees-cake had sav'd all this.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Why do you not make haste about your busines, but lose time with this Babler?

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Madam, will you give us leave to make use of your Coach?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: You may command it, Sir; when you have done, send him to the Exchange, where I'll dispatch a little business, and be with you immediately.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: So, this fire's kindled; put it out that can. What would not I give for a Peepers place at the meeting; I'll make haste, and it shall go hard but I'll bear my part of the mirth too.

div.head: ACT. V. SCEN. IV.
div.stage: Enter Widow, Pleasant, Careless, Wild, Parson, Jolly, Wanton and Secret: the Fidlers play as they come in.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: MAster Jolly, I find I am naturally inclin'd to mirth this day, and methinks my Corns ake more then my Horns; and to a man that has read Seneca a Cuckold ought to be no grief; especially in this Parish where I see such droves of St. Lukes cloathing; there's little Secret too, th'allay of waiting-woman, makes me hope, she may prove metal of the Parsons standard. Find a way to rid me of Wanton, and I'll put in to be Chaplain to this merry family; if I did not enveigle formal Secret, you should hang me; I know the trick on't; 'tis but praying too, and preaching of the waiting-woman, then carefully seeing her cushion laid, with her book and leaf turn'd down, do's it, with a few Anagrams, Acrosticks, and her name in the Register of my Bible: these charm the soft-soul'd sinner; then sometimes to read a piece of my Sermon, and tell her, a Saturday, where my Text shall be, spells that work more then Philtres.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: If you can be serious, we'l think of this at leisure.— See how they eye Wanton.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: What? consulting Parson? let us be judges betwixt you; d'ye hear, Jack, if he offers ready money, I counsel, as a friend, take it; for, By this light, if you refuse it, your wife will not; d'ye see those gay Petti-coats?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Yes, if you mean my wifes.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: You know th'are his, and she only wears 'em for his pleasure; and 'tis dangerous to have a wife under another mans Petticoats; what if you should find his breeches upon hers?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Are not you married too? take care that yours do's not wear the Breeches, another kind of danger, but as troublesome as that, or sore-eyes; and if she get but a trick of taking as readily as she's perswaded to give, you may find a horn at home; I have seen a Cuckold of your complexion; if he had had as much hoof as horn, you might have hunted the beast by his slat.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p:
How fine she is! and, By this light, a handsome wench, Mr. Jolly, I am easier perswaded to be reconcil'd to your fault, then any mans; I have seen, of this kind; her eyes have more Arguments in 'em then a thousand of those that seduce the world; hang me if those Quivers be not full of Darts; I could kiss that mouth,
my self, is this she my Aunt quarrel'd with you for?

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: The same, self-same. And by this hand, I was barbarous to her, for your Aunts sake; and had I not scap'd that mischief of matrimony, By this light, I had had never seen her again; but I was resolv'd not to quit her, till I was sure of a wife, for fear of what has follow'd; had I been such an Ass as to have left her upon the Aiery hopes of a widows Oaths; what a case had I been in now? You see, your Aunt's provided of a man. Bless him, and send him patience, 'twould have been fine to have seen me walking, and sighing upon cold hunting, seeking my whore again, or forc'd to make use of some common mercenary thing that sells sin and diseases, crimes, penance and sad repentance together; here's consolation and satisfaction, in Wanton, though a man lose his meal with the widow. And, faith, be free, how do you like my Girle; rid thee of her; what do's she want now, pray, but a joynture, to satisfie any honest man? speak your conscience; Ladies don't you think a little repentance, hereafter, will serve, for all the small sins that good nature can act with such a sinner?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, remember she's my wife; and be so civil to us both, as to forget these things.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: For that, Jack, we'l understand hereafter, 'tis but a trick of youth, man, and her jest ill make us both merry, I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, no more of your jestes, nor your Jack; remember my Coat and Calling. This familiarity both with my wife and my self, is not decent; your Clergy with Christen names are scarce held good Christians.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I wonder at nothing so much as M. Jollies mirth, to day; where lies his part of the jest? couzen'd or refus'd by all, not a fish that stays in's Net. Joll. bugs Wanton.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: No, what's this? shew me a fairer in all your streams; nor is this my single joy, who am pleas'd to find you may be couzen'd; rejoyce to see you may be brought to lie with a man for a jest; let me alone to fit you with a trick too.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Faith, it must be some new trick; for thou art so beaten at the old one, 'twill neither please thee nor her; besides, I mean to teach her that my self.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: I shall never be perfectly quiet in my mind, till I see some body as angry as my self; yet I have some consolation when I think on the wise plot that kill'd the Coach-man, how the Plague, Red-cross and Halberd has cut their fingers that design'd it, their anger will be perfect. Secret says they are coming, and that the Lady Love-all has given 'em the Alarm.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: And see where the parties come,— Storms and tempests in their minds, their looks are Daggers.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Servant, what? you'r melancholy and full of wonder; I see you have met the news.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Yes Madam, we have heard a report that will concern both your judgement and your honour.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, w'are innocent; 'tis meer predestination.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: All weddings, Mr. Sadd, you know goe by chance, like hanging.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: And, I thank my Stars, I have scap'd hanging; to ha' been his Bride had been both.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: This is not like the promise you made us yesterday.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why truly, Servant, I scarce know what I do yet; the fright of the Plague had so possess'd my mind with fear that I could think and dream of nothing, last night, but of a tall black man, that came and kiss'd me in my sleep, and slap'd his whip in mine Ears, 'twas a sawcy Ghost, (not unlike my Coach-man that's dead) and accus'd you of having a hand in his murder, and vow'd to haunt me till I was married, I told my niece the dream.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Nay, the Ghost sigh'd, and accus'd Secret and Master Sadd; of making him away confess, faith, had you a hand in that bloody jest?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Fie, Servant; could you be so cruel as to joyn with my woman against me?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: 'Tis well, Ladys; why a Pox do you look at me, this was your subtil plot; a Pox on your Clarks wit; you said the jest would beget a Comedy when 'twas known, and so I believe 'twill.

sp.speaker: Sad.
sp.p: Madam, I find you have discover'd our design, whose chief end was, to prevent this mischief which I doubt not, but you'le both live to repent your share of, before you have done travelling to the Epsams, Burbons, and the Spawes, to cure those travell'd diseases these Knights errant have, with Curiosity, sought out for you; 'Tis true, th' are mischiefs that dwell in pleasant Countries, yet those Roses have their thorns; and I doubt not, but these gentlemens wit may sting as well as please, sometime; and you may find it harder to satisfie their travail'd Experience, then to have suffer'd our home-bred ignorance.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Heark, if he be not fallen into a fit of his Cozen; These names of Places he has stollen out of her Receipt-book; amongst all whose diseases, find me any so dangerous, troublesome or incurable, as a fool, a lean, pale, sighing, coughing fool, that's rich and poor both, being born to an estate, without a mind or heart capable to use it, of a nature so miserable he grudges himself meat; nay, they say, he eats his meals twice, a fellow whose breath smells of yesterdays dinner, and stinks as if he had eat all our Suppers over again; I would advise you Mr. Sadd to sleep with your mouth open, to air it, or get the Brewer to Ton it; Faugh, an empty Justice, that stinks of the Lees and Casks, and belches Littleton and Ploydens Cases; dost thou think any woman that has wit, or honour, would kiss that Bung-hole; by this light, his head and belly look as blew and lank as French Rabbets, or stale Poultry; Alas, Sir, my Lady would have a husband to rejoyce with, no green-tail'd Lecturer, to stand Centry at his beds side, while his nasty soul scoures through him, sneaking out at the back door.— These, Sir, are diseases which neither the Spaw, or Bath, can cure your Garters and Willow are a more certain remedy.

sp.speaker: Constant.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I find our plot's betray'd, and we have patience left; 'Tis that damn'd Captain has inform'd.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p:
Yet 'tis one comfort, Madam, that you have miss'd that
man of war, that Knight of Finsbury; His Dowager, with Ale and Switches, would ha' bred a Ballad.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, you see what a difficulty it is, in this Age, for a woman to live honest, though she have a proper man to her husband; therefore it behoves us to consider, who we choose.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: The Lady has Reason; for being allow'd but one, who would choose such weazel's as we see daily mary'd, that are all head and Tail, crooked, dirty, sold Vermin, predestin'd for Cuckolds, painted Snails, with houses on their backs, and horns as big as Dutch Cows; would any woman marry such? nay, can any woman be honest, that lets such Hod-man-dods crawle o're her Virgin breast, and Belly, or suffer 'em to leave their slimy paths upon their bodies onely for Joyntures? Out, 'tis Mercenary and base; The generous heart has onely the Laws of Nature and kindness in her view; and when she will oblige, Friend is all the ties that nature seeks, who can both bear and excuse those kind crimes; And I believe, one as poor as the despis'd Captain, and neglected Courtier, may make a woman as happy in a Friendship as Master Sadd, who has as many faults as we have debts; one, whose Father had no more credit with Nature, then ours had with Fortune; whose soul wears Rags as well as the Captains body.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Nay then, I'le laugh; for I perceive, y'are angryer then we; Alas, has lost both ventures, Wanton, and the Widow.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Both, and neither so unlucky as to be thy wife; thy face is hang'd with blacks already, we may see the Bells toll in thy Eyes; A Bride and a Wedding Shirt? a Sexton and a winding sheet? a Scrivener to draw up Joyntures? A Parson to make thy will, man; by this light hee's as Chap-fallen as if he had layen under the Table all night.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Faith, Master Sadd, hee's parlously in the right; ne're think of marrying in this dull clime, wedlock's a trade you'le ne're go through with; wives draw-bills upon sight, and't will not be for your credit to protest 'em; rather follow my counsel, and Marry la Venetiano for a night and away; a Pistol Joynture do's it; then 'tis but repenting in the morning, and leave your woman, and the sin both, i'th Bed; But if you play the fool, like your friends, and Marry in serious earnest, you may repent it too, as they do; but wher's the remedy?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What was't you said, Sir, do you repent?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: By this hand, Widow, I don't know; but we have pursu'd a jest a great way. Parson, are you sure w'are married.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Yes, I warrant you, for their escaping.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Their escaping? fool, thou mistak'st me, ther's no fear of that; but I would fain know, if there be no way for me to get out of this Nooze; No hole to hide a mans head in from this Wedlock?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Not any, but what I presume shee'le shew you anon.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p:
Hum! Now do I feel all my fears flowing in upon me; Wanton and Mistriss Pleasant both grow dangerously handsome, a Thousand Graces in each, I never observed before, now, just now,
when I must not taste, I begin to long for some of their Plums.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Is this serious, Sir?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Yes truly, Widow, sadly serious; Is there no way to get three or four mouthfulls of Kisses from the Parsons wife?

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: This is sad, Sir, upon my Wedding day, to despise me, for such a Common thing.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: As sad, as I could wish; This is a jest makes me laugh.— Common? no Madam, that's two bitter, she's forrest only, where the Royal Chace is as free as Fair.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Were not you a Widow to day?

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: Yes faith, Girl, and as foolish a one as ever Coach jumbled out of joynt.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: Stay then till to morrow, and tell me the difference betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: I hope, thou'lt prove a She-prophet; could I live to see thee turn honest wife, and she the Wanton Widow.

sp.speaker: VVant.
sp.p: I cannot but laugh, to see how easie it is, to lose or win the opinion of the world; a little custom heals all, or else what's the difference betwixt a Married Widow and one of us? can any woman be pure, or worth the serious sighing of a Generous heart, that has had above one hand lay'd upon her? is there place to write above one Lovers name, with honour, in her heart; 'tis indeed for one a Royal Palace; but if it admits of more, an Hospitall, or an Inne, at best, as well as ours; only off from the Road, and less frequented.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Shrewdly urg'd.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: And though the sins of my Family threw me into want, and made me subject to the treachery of that broken faith, to whose perjury I owe all my Crimes, yet still I can distinguish betwixt that folly and this honour, which must tell you; He or she that would be thought twice so, was never once a Lover.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Parson, thou art fitted; A whore, and Apothegms! what sport will she make us under a Tree, with a Sallad, and sayings, in the Summer?

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Come, Wanton, no fury; you see my Aunt's angry.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: So am I, Sir, and yet can calmly reason this truth; Marryed Widows, though chaste to the Law and Custom, yet their second Hymens make that which was but dying in the first husbands Bed, a stain in the second sheets, where all their kindness and repeated embraces want their value, because they're sully'd and have lost their Lustre.

sp.speaker: Sadd.
sp.p: By this light, I'le go to School to Wanton, she has open'd my Eyes, and I begin to believe I have scap'd miraculously; By this hand, wench, I was within an inch of being marryed to this Danger; for what can we call these second submissions, but a tolerated lawful Mercenaryness, which though it be a rude and harsh expression, yet your Carriage deserves it.

sp.speaker: Pleas.
sp.p: Fy, Master Sadd, pray leave being witty; I fear, 'tis a mortal sin, to begin in the fifth Act of your Days upon an old subject too, abusing of Widows, because they despise you.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Alas, Niece, let him alone, he may come in, for his share; the Parson, that has so oft receiv'd 'em, will not refuse him Tythes, there, in Charity.

sp.speaker: Want.
sp.p: That, or Conveniency, Interest, or Importunity, may, by your Example prevail; But 'tis not fair play, Madam, to turn your Lover to the Common, as you call it, now hee's rid lean in your service; take heed, Mr. Careless, and warning Mr. Sadd; you see how fit for the Scavengers team your Lady leaves her Lovers.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Such a Lecture before I had Marry'd would ha' made me have considered of this matter. D'ost thou hear Wanton, let us forgive one another, being Marry'd, for that folly has made us guilty alike.

sp.speaker: VVant.
sp.p: And I would fain know the difference betwixt ours, and a wedding crime, which is worst; to let love, youth and good humor betray us to a kindness, or to be gravely seduc'd by some aunt or uncle, without consideration of the disparity of Age, Birth, or Persons, to lie down before a Joynture; Ladies, you may flatter your selves, but the ingenuous part of the world cannot deny, but such minds, had they been born where our faults are not only tolerated but protected, would have listned to the same things, Interest counsels thereto.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Parson, what Boot betwixt Our Wives? either come to a Price, or draw off your Doxy.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Propose, propose, here will be mirth anon.

sp.speaker: Sad.
sp.p: Yes, yes, propose, while I break it to your Lady; Madam, you see, here's a proper man to be had, and money to boot— what, dumb?

sp.speaker: VVant.
sp.p: No, shee's onely thinking; faith, Madam, try 'em both to Night, and choose tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: Come, no more of this; Aunt, take my word for your husband, that have had more experience of him then all these; 'tis true, he will long for these Girles, as children do for plums; and when h'as done, make a meal upon cheese; and you must not wonder, nor quarrel at what he says in his humor, but Judge him by his Actions; and when he is in his fit, and raves most, put him into your bed, and fold him close in your Arms, Aunt; if he do's not rise as kind and as good a husband as he that sings Psalms best, hang me; why, you're a fool, aunt; a widow, & dislike a longing Bridegroom! I thought you had known better; do you love a spurr'd horse, rather then a Duker, that neighs, and scrapes? I would not say this, but that I know him; let him not go out of your sight, for hee's now in season, a Ripe mature husband; No delays; if you let him hang longer upon hope his fruit will fall alone.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You are merry, Sir; But if I had known this humor. She kisses Carl. and he kisses her twice

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: You'd ha' kiss'd him first; but being ignorant, let me make you blush; come, a kiss, and all's Friends.— how now, Sir, agen, agen, Aunt, look to your self.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Um! By this light, sweet heart, and I thank thee; Nay widow, there's no jesting with these things— Nay, I am a Lyon, in my Kisses her again .Love: Aware, Puss, if you flatter me, for I shall deceive you.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Since all are couzen'd, why should I be troubled at my fortune; faith Gentlemen, what will you two give me for a wife, betwixt you?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Faith, they're mischiefs deare bought, though a man get 'em for nothing.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: I'me almost of his mind; and if other people find no more pleasure in a marri'd life then I, upon my wedding day, I'de pass my time in the Piazza, with the Mountebank, and let him practise upon my Teeth, and draw'em too ere he perswades the words of matrimony out of my mouth again. I, I, M. Constant, you may laugh, you ha miss'd a wife; would I were in your case, the world should see how chearfully I should bear such an affliction.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Jack, I ha made my peace at home, and by seeing others ship-wrack'd will avoid the danger, and here resolve, never to sigh again for any woman; th'are weeds grow in ev'ry hedge; and transplanting of'em thus to our Beds gives certain trouble, seldom pleasure, never profit.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: See where the enemy comes; now if you be wise, arm, and unite against him, as a common foe; he's come from his old Lady, designing a reconciliation; the Rogue's provident, and would fain have a Nest for his Age to rest in; Buff and Feathers do well in the youth and heat of thirty; but in the winter of old age, Captain at threescore, lame and lean, may lie with the Almanack out of date.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: The Parson's grown witty, and prophesies upon the strength of Bride-Cake; if I guess aright, thou'lt be hang'd; for 'tis a truth, I have been endeavouring to make it appear, her fears were mistaken in me: but I find the witch more implacable then the Devil; the waiting-woman is harder to forgive her part, then my Lady. Faithful will not be reconcil'd, the merciless Baud is all fire and sword, no quarter; Bless me from an old waiting-womans wrath; she'l never forgive me the disappointing her of a promise when I was drunk; her Lady and she are coming, but in such a fury, I would not have the storm find you in the street; therefore. I counsel you to avoid the boys, and take shelter in the next house.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: No, let's home, and with all diligence get our dinner, to defend us; and let the Porter dispute it at the wicket, till she signs Articles of peace.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Agreed.—

div.stage: Careless is kind to the Widow; as he goes out, Wild and Pleasant go together, Jolly and the Parsons wife go together.

sp.speaker: Wild.
sp.p: See how they pair now, 'tis not threescore year will part 'em now he has tasted a kiss or two.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: Parson, I'll be your Bride-man.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: 'Tis well, Sir, I shall ha my time too.

sp.speaker: Joll.
sp.p: I by this hand; nay, we'l share fairly.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That's but reason, Wanton; and since he grows tame, use him kindly for my sake.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Can any of you digest Spunge and Arsenick?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Arsenick? what's that?

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p:
An Italian Sallad, which I'll dress for you, By Jove, er'e I'll walk in my Canonical-coat lin'd with horn; Death, if I suffer this, we shall have that damn'd Courtier pluck on his shooes with the Parsons Musons; fine y'faith, none but the small Levites brow
to plant your shooing-horn-feed in?— How now? As he is going off the Capt. Stays him.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Prithee, Jack, stay, and say something to the Gentlemen, by way of Epilogue. Thou art a piece of a scurvey Poet thy self, prithee oblige the Author, and give us a line or two in praise of his Play.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: I oblige him? hang him and all his friends, and hurt no body; yes, I'me likely to speak for him; you see how i'ha been us'd to day betwixt you, I shall find a time to be reveng'd, let go my cloak; I have a Province, within, of mine own to govern, let me go.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Who, thy wife? faith stay, and give them an opportunity; thy pain will be the sooner over: you see 'tis a thing resolv'd betwixt 'em, and now thou'rt satisfi'd in the matter, be wise and silent; who knows what good she may do thee another time; I dare say, if she had as many souls in her as she had men, she'd bring thee a cure of her self.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Let me go, or I shall be as troublesome as you are injurious, for all your Titles, Sir.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Lend me your cloak then, to appear more decent; you'd not ha me present Epilogue in Buff, whorson Dunce, with a red nose.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Sir, my business is praying, not Epilogues.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: With that face? By this light, 'tis a scandal to see it flaming so neer the altar; thou look'st as if thou'dst cry tope, in the face of the Congregation, instead of Amen.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Thou'rt an Ass, 'tis proper there, t'has zeal and fervor in't, and burns before the Altar like the primitive Lamps.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I cry thee mercy; By this light, he'l make it sacriledge anon to steal his nose; thou'lt entitle the Altar to that Coal; was't not kindl'd Ex voto? nay, I will have your cloak.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Take it; would 'twere Nessus his shirt, for you and your Poets sake.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What, do's the Rogue wish 'twere made of Nettles?

div.stage: Captain puts on his Cloak, and addresses himself to speak the Epilogue, and is interrupted by the Lady Love-all and Faithfull her woman, who in haste and full of anger pull him by the Cloak.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: By your favour, Sir; did you see any company pass this way? The Musick playes.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: None, but the three Brides, and they are gone just before you.— Hark, the Musick will guide you.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Is it certain then they re married?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes, Lady, I saw the Churches rights performed.

sp.speaker: Faithf.
sp.p: Why do's your Ladiship lose time in talking with this fellow; don't you know him, Madam? 'tis the rascally Captain, hid in a black cloak; I know you, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: She has reason; now I mark him better, I should know that false face too; see Faithful, there are those treacherous eyes still.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Alas, you mistake me, Madam, I am Epilogue now; the Captain's within; and as a friend I counsel you, not to incense the Gentlemen against the Poet, for he knows all your story; and if you anger him he'l put it in a Play; but if you'l do friendly offices, I'll undertake, instead of your Pearl you lost, to help you to the Jewel, the Scotch Dictionary will tell you the value of it; let them go alone, and fret not at their loss; stay, and take my counsel, it shall be worth three revenges.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Well, what is't, Sir?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: They say, you have a great power over the Parson; if you can prevail with him to express his anger in some Satyrick Comedy (for the knave has wit, and they say his genius lies that way,) tell him, 'tis expected he should be revenged upon the illiterate Courtier that made this Play; if you can bring this business about, I may find a way, as Epilogue, to be thankful, though the Captain abus'd you to day. Think on't, Stephen is as handsome, when the Play is done, as Mr. Wild was in the Scene.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: There's something of reason in what he says.— But my friend, how shall one believe you; you that were such a Rascal to day, in Buff, is it to be hoped you can be honest only with putting on a black cloak? well, I'll venture once again; and if I have any power, he shall sting the malicious Rascal; and I think he is fit for such a business. I'me sure he has the worst tongue; and a conscience that neither honour nor truth binds; and therefore 'tis to be believed, if he will rail in publick he may be even with your Poet; I will cloath and feed him and his Muse this seven years, but I will plague him: Secret tells me, 'twas your Poet too that pawn'd me, to day, in the Tavern.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: By my faith, did he; nay 'twas he that told me of your friendship with Jolly.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I wonder the Parson has been so long silent; a man of his coat and parts, to be beaten with a pen, by one that speaks sence by rote, like Parots; one that knows not why sence is sence, but by the sound; one that can scarce read, nay, not his own hand; well, remember your promise.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Leave it to me, he is yours; and if our Plot take, you shall all have your shares in the mirth; but not the profit of the Play; and the Parson, more then his Tythe, a second day.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: We will discourse of this some other time; and pray dispatch what 'tis you have to say to this noble company, that I may be gone; for those Gentlemen will be in such fury, if I stay; and think, because we are alone, God knows what.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter what they think, 'tis not them we are to study now; but these guests, to whom pray address your self civilly, and beg that they would please to become Fathers, and give those Brides within; what say you, Gentlemen, will you lend your hands to joyn them; the Match you see is made; if you refuse, Stephen misses the Wench, and then you cannot justly blame the Poet. For you know, they say, that alone is enough to spoil the Play.
